Whaling Ms ANNETTE ELLIS (Canberra) (4.01 pm)-I rise today to speak on the government’s failure, as I see it, to protect some of nature’s most graceful and magnificent creatures: the humpback and minke whales. These wonderful gentle giants of the sea, renowned for their long oceanic treks around the world, their unique communal hunting, communications and social activities, are still unforgivably being hunted and killed. But, what is worse, they are being killed and slaughtered in Australian territorial waters. Many people today may be thinking to themselves, ‘Hang on. Surely we banned that sort of thing ages ago.’ And they would be right in thinking that. Whaling was officially banned in Australian waters in 1981 when the Whale Protection Act 1980 came into effect. This was back in time when Australia was one of the leaders in the international efforts to protect whales. Australia also played a key role in the declaration of the Southern Ocean Whale Sanctuary in 1994. Under Australia’s Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999, it is made very clear that killing whales in the Australian Antarctic Territory is illegal. Whales in Australian waters are protected by Australian law and it is time the government enforced its own legislation. The Prime Minister’s 2001 election policy on whales stated: The government has strengthened domestic legislation protecting Australia’s whale and dolphin species. Under the EPBC Act, Australia’s entire Exclusive Economic Zone has been formally declared the Australian Whale Sanctuary. This offers unprecedented protection for all [whales and dolphins]. Since 1994, the Australian Antarctic Territory has been part of our exclusive economic zone. However, since 2000 Japanese factory ships have slaughtered over 400 whales within Australia’s waters as part of Japan’s notorious ‘scientific’ whaling program. Australia has a proud history on environmental issues such as preventing the slaughter of whales. Given this proud record, current moves by Japan to increase its killing of whales should be strongly opposed. Unfortunately, the values of those progressive and enlightened governments of the past do not seem to be reflected by the federal government today. I would like to congratulate, however, the state and territory governments who have joined with the federal opposition in condemning the Howard government for its failure to effectively oppose the proposed slaughter of humpback whales and the proposed increase in the slaughter of minke whales. Reconciliation Dr STONE (Murray-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration (4.03 pm)-In this week, when we are thinking about reconciliation-the ongoing business of bringing our various races in Australia towards a better understanding of each other’s history-I thought it would be useful to remind ourselves of how far we have come. I want to refer to a document that is in a book that I had published in the 1970s called Aborigines in White Australia. It is a documentary history of the attitudes affecting official policy and the Australian Aborigines between 1697 and 1973. This is a quote from the Hansard of the progress report of the Royal Commission on the Aborigines, in July 1913. It comes from the South Australian parliamentary papers. The chairman, the Hon. J Jelly, asks Mr EC Stirling, an expert in Indigenous affairs at the time, stated: I would like to refer to the half-caste children. My opinion is that the more of those half-caste children you can get away from their parents and place under the care of the State the better. I think you should take them at an early age. Supposing they were taken charge of by the State Children’s Department it would be easier to deal with them if they were taken when they have the attractiveness of infancy. There is always something attractive in the infants of all races, whatever be the color. You would get people to take those children young who might be disinclined to take them when they were older. I think that it is the best way to save the half-caste children-take them away from their surroundings. When they are caught young they are far less inclined to revert to their old state. There is a strong tendency among the half-castes when they have grown up to go back to the ways of the natives. They are far less likely to do that after they have had a long contact with civilization. The Hon. J Jelly asks: What would be a suitable age to remove them? Mr Stirling answered: I think when they are about 2 or 3 years of age. The question was asked: You would not recommend that they be taken away when they are absolute infants? Answer from Mr Stirling: No; because then you would have the burden of them that all children are at such a young age. When they are a couple of years of age they do not require so much attention and they are young enough to be attractive. Question from Hon. J Jelly: Do you think that their experience of two years with the black mother would seriously interfere with them? MAIN COMMITTEE

I have spoken to a lawyer representing Cornelia Rau and I am aware of work by the University of Newcastle Legal Centre. There are clear problems with the Palmer inquiry. It is no reflection on his integrity, simply a question of the process. Unlike a judicial proceeding, you cannot test the evidence. We do not know what evidence has been provided to Mr Palmer, so lawyers cannot ask questions about it, challenge the claims, collect relevant dissenting opinions and so on. One of the lawyers at least has had experience in dealing with DIMIA-the recent case in the South Australian Supreme Court is illustrative. Only after systematic questioning and independent psychiatric evidence did a clear picture emerge of the treatment of two detainees in Baxter. Rau’s lawyer has also been refused funding to enable independent psychiatric assessment or to pursue the questioning of witnesses-mainly detainees who are reluctant to give evidence to Mr Palmer for fear there may be retribution in their cases. The University of Newcastle Legal Centre, acting on behalf of the family, have also raised serious questions about the adequacy of the Palmer inquiry. Limited powers and narrow terms of reference might not allow the identification of systemic failures and those who are responsible for them-it is about what happened, and not why. As I mentioned, there is no protection for detainees alleging potential criminal misconduct. Two such people approached me while I was at Baxter and I have passed that information on to Mr Palmer. But, again, those people are not available for direct testimony. It appears from the terms of reference that the Palmer inquiry will not address questions of the lawfulness of Rau’s detention and may fail to look at the question of her treatment and the provision of adequate care. In my view anyone who is in the sick culture that now pervades DIMIA is unlikely to get adequate care. Palmer is already reported as recommending an open inquiry with judicial powers, after some 200 more cases have been dumped in his lap. He suggests that the Ombudsman might be an appropriate person to conduct that inquiry. I want to argue today, very briefly, against that proposition, based on my own experience with the Ombudsman’s inquiry into the December 2003 disturbances in Port Hedland. At my request the Ombudsman undertook inquiries. DIMIA appointed Keith Hamburger to conduct an internal investigation. The Ombudsman determined that it was ‘professional and independent’. He wrote to me outlining briefly 67 findings and 37 recommendations. The key ones would have prevented what has just happened in Baxter if they had ever been made public and acted upon. He reassured me that the MAIN COMMITTEE inappropriate detention of people in management support units and their inadequate care would be the subject of change by the department. I have never been able to get a copy of that report under FOI. It remains languishing somewhere on someone’s desk in DIMIA. More than a year ago this material would have been available to the department and in the public arena and I believe would have prevented what has happened to Cornelia Rau and others. We need a full, public, open inquiry, with proper testing of the evidence, and with commitments from the department to systemic change, which is clearly the problem in this case. No more pussyfooting around. MAIN COMMITTEE Bambi Kindergarten issue of concern to families and an issue that impacts on workplaces. Not unsurprisingly, it is an issue that constituents of my electorate of Werriwa are also concerned about. I bring this issue to the attention of members not simply to pass comment on the government’s child-care policies but to draw the attention of members to the case of the Bambi Kindergarten in Ingleburn. Bambi Kindergarten is a not-for-profit preschool run by the community and established in 1952. It is currently facing eviction because the land on which it stands has been allocated by the Department of Defence to the new Edmondson Park development. The Bambi Kindergarten was established by the wives of soldiers serving in Korea. It acted as a support centre for families as well as an early childhood education centre. Edmondson Park development is not new and I do not stand here today objecting to it. I object to the actions taken by the Department of Defence, in being unwilling to secure some land within the development to retain this facility. I toured the facility in my by-election campaign and was informed by the kindergarten that on several occasions they had been provided with verbal assurances that the land would be secure and the lease renewed. Sadly, this facility is far from secure as the department has backed away from these assurances. Bambi Kindergarten has recently been offered a further, but final, annual lease. Needless to say, this news was received poorly. It left the management, staff and current users of the facility, as well as the community, generally questioning this government’s commitment to the provision of child care. Through the shadow minister for defence and homeland security, the Minister for Defence has been approached to consider options such as gifting the land and allowing the kindergarten to remain or assisting the kindergarten to secure alternative accommodation. To date, I have yet to receive a response from the minister. This kindergarten has a unique historical association with Australia’s defence community. I encourage the minister to intervene to make sure that it can continue to provide high-quality child-care services to the people of Prestons, Horningsea Park, Macquarie Links, Ingleburn and of course Edmondson Park. Child-care places are scarce enough. Why exacerbate the situation by closing down a facility with 200 child-care places per week, a facility that provides affordable child-care services and that has served the community for well over 50 years? Honours and Awards: Medals Lyons and his comments, and I agree with him entirely. I would like to raise the matter of wearing of unofficial, purchased or commemorative medals on the left breast. Following the 2005 ANZAC Day ceremonies it was brought to my attention that several personnel were wearing bought, unofficial medals together with their official medals on their left breast. I know that many veterans have also approached the President of the Townsville branch of the RSL, Rod McLeod, about this concerning matter. Australia’s honours and awards system has been recognised throughout the world as being beyond reproach. Medals have never been awarded without detailed justification. Indeed, the recently amended Defence Legislation Amendment Bill increased penalties awarded for personnel wearing official medals to which they have no entitlement. However, there has been no corresponding legislation to preclude anyone-veteran or nonveteran-from buying any number of unofficial medals and wearing these on their left breast, either with or without official medals. To the general public these people appear to be veterans who have rendered invaluable service to our nation. In reality, they are denigrating the real official medals worn with justifiable pride by veterans. Many of these official medals have been awarded for active service which has involved, sadly, loss of life or which has seen personnel wounded physically or psychologically. If we do not do something to preclude the wearing of these unofficial medals on the left breast, our highly regarded honours and awards system will become a sham. I am aware that a succession of ministers has indeed examined this particular issue and, unfortunately, the gobbledegook that comes back from the department has to be seen to be believed. The demands for the services of working women’s centres are growing the more the labour market is deregulated. It would be a great tragedy if the New South Wales centre is forced to close. In its 10 years of service to working women it has developed a particular expertise in the interface between employment and discrimination law. Although there are cattle farmers in my electorate, the livestock farmers are predominantly sheep farmers and I know that these measures will be particularly welcome. In an electorate such as Pearce, which covers around 26,000 square kilometres, roads are a very big issue. We have been very pleased that our minister has committed large sums of money in the past to improve the two main arterial roads-the Great Eastern Highway, which connects my electorate and indeed, WA, to the eastern seaboard, and the Great Northern Highway, which runs through my electorate connecting the northern pastoral and mining areas to the city, the airport and the wharf at Fremantle. So they are particularly important roads. Over the years these roads have fallen into disrepair. It is also true to say that the volume and the extent of traffic traversing these roads has grown enormously, with a lot of large trucking, as you can imagine, coming down from the northern mining areas. These trucks have increasingly taken to the roads and the roads are just not adequate to deal with them. With the intersection of these two roads-one from the east one from the north-west-the works take on important dimensions for industries, businesses and tourism within the Pearce electorate. When we talk about roads we have to think about the mums and dads and the ordinary folk who have to use those roads every day to take kids to school, and we have to think about the school buses that run every day in a country electorate. It is of increasing concern to the general public that these roads are in a safe condition for all kinds of traffic. It is very pleasing now to see the work taking place to improve a very large section of the Great Eastern Highway between Sawyers Valley and The Lakes. That is a very welcome improvement to what has been a notorious stretch of road which has caused the deaths of a number of people. A further $3 million of the funding will be used to build the Clackline bypass in 2006-07. I know my constituents will be pleased with the news that black spot funding will continue, as it has been used on many occasions to deal with particularly dangerous conditions such as poor visibility, surface works and widening and alignment in particularly bad spots of the road-and there are many. Earlier in the year, $330,000 was allocated to improving a roundMAIN COMMITTEE about in the town of Northam, which I have spoken about as the town of the ecohouse, and an improvement to a section of the northern Cranbrook Road south of Beverly was allocated $250,000. I would like to put on record that I am grateful for the work of the local community groups and shires that keep me up to date with problem areas and assist me with presentations to our minister to ensure that the roads in the electorate are safe. I am often out on the road with community groups, looking at dangerous spots. They are always the eyes and ears of the electorate and I find it very useful to have these people alerting me to various difficult transport or road safety issues. Moving away from the subject of roads and the economy, can I say that it is heartening to see money being given to carers in this budget. That builds on previous budgets. I had the great pleasure of being the Minister for Family Services when the Howard government first took office. The Prime Minister took a very personal interest in the issue of carers. It was not until the Howard government came in that carers were substantially given a voice in this place. The Prime Minister recognised that many families in our communities care for chronically ill people, people with profound disabilities and the elderly, and that they were doing that with very little support from government a few years ago. In almost every budget, the government has sought to improve the situation for those many families around the nation who care for other members of the family. There is increased support for families and I know that it will be of great assistance to those who care for a family member who is chronically ill, profoundly disabled or ageing. Targeted funding to specific areas of health, including cancer care and dementia, are also welcome announcements. Cancer is a disease that touches the lives of most people at some time. Funding for screening, which allows early intervention, is a measure to save lives that is well known in the medical profession. I am also pleased to see health measures that will target young people, with a youth campaign to discourage young people from taking up smoking. In addition to that, we have had some important changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. I know that it requires people to make a small contribution to the cost of their medications. The Treasurer pointed out, and it is important for us all to understand, the cost of many life-extending drugs. The Treasurer used the case of Herceptin, which is used to treat breast cancer. The cost of that drug is around $50,000 to $100,000 per patient per year. Having established in this House an informal backbench group concerned about diabetes, I know that there are many advances in many areas of medicine and pharmaceuticals. These are often life-saving advances. If everyone makes a small contribution to the cost of the medications that they receive to enhance and improve the quality of their lives, it means that more drugs can become available to more people with serious illnesses and, hopefully, either sustain life or improve the quality of life. That is certainly the case with diabetes where there have been some very important advances in recent years with medications that can prevent the early onset of the worse aspects of diabetes, type 2 in particular. It is important that we ask people to make some contribution towards the cost of their medications so that we can ensure that all Australians have access to life-saving and life-enhancing medications. The Treasurer made the point, and I think it is true, that sometimes, if people get medications for nothing, there can be a tendency towards hoarding. That is quite well documented. MAIN COMMITTEE Many people-I guess we are all guilty of it-have medications in their medical cabinet that are unused and that are subsidised quite heavily by government. However, the centrepiece of the budget is the tax cuts, and these have been made possible through the ability of the Howard government to manage the economy. We expect the economy to grow steadily at three per cent in 2005-06. Unemployment is now at a 28-year low, and it is anticipated that that will stay at a low level. A strong economy with low unemployment is one of the most positive ways to ensure that all Australians improve their circumstances. Having the opportunity to work is one of the best ways to avoid the poverty traps that so many families on welfare face and, along with tax cuts for all taxpayers, I am broadly supportive of the Welfare to Work measures and the money that the government has committed to assisting people to move from welfare to work. I say ‘broadly supportive’ because we must watch this support very carefully. Raising children alone is a very onerous task, and people with a disability have an added challenge in accessing the work force. These people need a lot of support. Adequate child care, decent wages, opportunities to improve education and skill levels, and access to transport and workplaces are all key issues for these people. It is my hope that we will closely monitor the implementation of this policy to ensure adequate support. In the short time. I have left, I pause to address the issue of mental health. I have spoken to our government about the concerns I have for people with mental health issues and their access to the work force. Most of these people want to work and are very capable of working, MAIN COMMITTEE but many of them have an illness which is of an episodic nature and sometimes renders them unable to work on an episodic basis. For them, finding consistent employment is sometimes quite a challenge. I think we have a deficiency in our response across the whole mental health system, particularly at the state level. It is important that we are mindful of some of the most disadvantaged and poorest in our community and that we always ensure that, in the implementation of the policies, these people are given fair access to supporting services. on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2005-2006 and related bills, about a subject that I have canvassed on many occasions. It relates to government and it relates to regulation. It relates to government’s role in regulating predatory practices by major corporations with enormous market power who exercise that power on a group of small businesses. This is an issue that I have raised over several years in the hope that the government would take some action to protect the rights of a number of small business people around the country. I am speaking about the motor vehicle insurance industry and its relationship with the smash repair industry. In particular I want to talk about the predatory behaviour of the motor vehicle insurance companies and the consequences of that predatory behaviour. I believe-and in this place I am going to cite an incident-that the practices of these major insurance companies are creating the preconditions for a potentially lethal accident. The practices that they are forcing crash repairers to indulge in are resulting in unsafe cars being put back onto the street. That is a disgrace. Government has a responsibility to ensure that predatory practices being perpetrated by the major vehicle insurance companies on the vehicle smash repairers are stopped, and it does have the capacity to actually do this. I am aware of the fact that there is a Productivity Commission report of an inquiry into the smash repair business, a report which is currently being considered by the Treasurer. I believe it was handed to the Treasurer on 18 March. My understanding is that he has 25 sitting days to form a response. I say to the Treasurer that, in contemplating his response to the Productivity Commission report, he needs to look at, potentially, a mandatory code of practice. There has been some form of discussion in the past about a voluntary code of conduct or practice. My belief, from the experience that I have in talking to smash repair businesses across the country, is that we have gone past the point where it should be just a voluntary code of practice. There are too many incidents where major vehicle insurance companies are using their market power to force unsafe working practices on smash repairers. From a personal perspective, I just do not think a voluntary code is going to be satisfactory. I think there needs to be some legislative instrument that can be used. The motor vehicle insurance industry, around the 2000-01 period, had revenues of about $5 billion in premiums. So that is $5 billion in the year 2000-01 out of a total insurance pool nationally of about $21 billion. It is interesting that more than 90 per cent of all motor vehicle insurance business is done by just four companies: IAG, Suncorp, Promina and Allianz. What that means is that there are four companies with enormous market share. They have a sort of symbiotic relationship with about 5,000 smash repairers across the country. I have raised in this place before some of my concerns about the insurance companies’ use of unqualified assessors. These are people who, in my experience and from what I have been told by the smash repair businesses, are sent by insurance companies to deduce the value of the insurance repairs required to put a car back on the road. speaker: Mr Byrne (Holt) (4.49 Pm)
theText: I rise to speak in this place this evening, during the debatesome of the documents that I have cited quite clearly indicates that these people are simply not qualified to be making that assessment. In a sense, what they are also doing is creating artificially low assessment prices and then forcing the crash repairers to accept those prices. The other thing they are doing is using incentive programs to drive down the cost of a motor vehicle quotation by an assessor. This document from a major insurance company says, in writing, what happens if you meet certain benchmark standards or go underneath benchmark standards. You quote an average price for a vehicle. If in your overall pool of insurance assessment you meet a target where the quote falls below that, you get a bonus. This is a bonus for assessors to underquote on the real cost of smash repairs. When that happens, the smash repairers are forced to repair the car at a lower cost. These issues have been raised in the past and nothing has been done. But adding to that, and giving the Treasurer something to think about when he is contemplating this report by the Productivity Commission, are two further issues. One is the issue of cash settling. What has happened in recent times is that the insurance companies have basically asked the smash repairers to sign an agreement where they become a preferred repairer. That means thatparticularly for someone who has been a preferred smash repairer for 20 or 30 years-if they sign the agreement with the insurance company and that preferred repairer is not on the list, then they have to pay in some cases an additional premium to access that preferred repairer. But what is also happening is that a lot of smash repairers are being forced into a very restrictive arrangement with these major insurance companies. If a vehicle is smashed and needs repairing, the person-under RACV, for example-is obliged to go to the preferred repairers nominated by the insurance company. That sounds really good, but I question the relationship between those preferred repairers and the RACV, particularly when these people are relying upon them for customers, given the market share they have. I want to read a particular insight from a smash repairer who had some dealings with this and was very concerned about being forced into a preferred repairer agreement with the IAG. I will just read onto the record-and he has asked me to do this-some of his concerns about this. The document is titled ‘Paying for freedom of choice’ and reads: IAG Insurance intends to include a new provision in Motor Insurance Policies from November 15th 2004. That has already been done. The document continues: The inclusion will allow the policyholder to have freedom of choice in regard to who will repair their vehicle after an accident. This freedom of choice will cost the consumer an estimated $69.30 on top of their normal Comprehensive Insurance policy. It would appear the idea behind this venture is to achieve something IAG have been working on for several years. Basically the consumer (who believes they won’t have an accident and only take out insurance to be responsible and in case of bad luck) by not taking out the freedom of choice levy will hand over complete control and the right for IAG to do as they wish with the policyholder’s vehicle. The majority of the Auto Body Repair Industry in Victoria and NSW have signed IAG’s associate smash repair contract. In doing so, they have had to invest on online imaging and claims handling systems, which was part of the requirements after signing. The repairers were promised that, after becomMAIN COMMITTEE ing an ASR repairer, the arrangement and new equipment would simplify assessments and generally make it easier to do business with IAG. The new so-called freedom of choice policy (unless the vast majority of IAG clients takes it out) will completely do away with all ASR arrangements and the investments made by repairers. As failure by the insured to pay the extra levy on a policy renewal will take anyone other than a preferred IAG repairer out of the equation and do away with the insured’s freedom of choice. This exercise by IAG is nothing more than an effort to take control of vehicles they insure by using smoke and mirrors and relying on motorists gambling on whether or not they will have an accident. Freedom of choice for the consumer is supposedly a normal and expected part of life in Australia and something the ACCC was commissioned to protect and uphold for both the consumer and business communities alike. And certainly not an issue that can be used by a large company to take control of smaller competitors and the consumer. The fact that IAG has proposed such a schemeand it has been implementedshows contempt for both the Auto Body Industry and consumers alike. Especially at a time when the Government inquiry into the Body Repairer and Insurance industry relationship is currently being held. … … … If this policy is rubber stamped by the ACCC, it will have a catastrophic effect on the Body Repair Industry and open the door for the Insurance industry to put in place other such methods of control. It is signed ‘from a cranky crash repairer’-I will not read out the exact words. In a sense, what you have is an enormous insurance company with enormous leverage and market power forcing smaller businesses into an arrangement which does not provide freedom of choice. What happens to significant crash repair companies that are reputable and have been in the game but do not want to do this? What happens is that they are subjected, particularly if they have had an agreement with the RACV, to an operation called cash settling. If you are a crash repairer and you do not want to be an approved repairer or to sign that RACV contract or be an associate repairer, they say, ‘If a person comes to you and is insured by us and wants to get the car fixed up, normally we would ensure a fairly smooth process but unfortunately we are going to pay the customer directly after some period of time and then they can pay you.’ This is a standover tactic by major insurance companies over small crash repairers. Most crash repairers are small businesses. On average they employ six or fewer people. I want to refer to some documents that I have received from some of these smash repairers who feel very uncomfortable about what they are being subjected to. I contend that it is an abuse of market power. I will read these into the record; I have been asked to do this by the people concerned. The first document reads as follows: To whom it may concern Delphic Cove Pty Ltd has been providing the RACV with panel beating services since 1983. In that time, we have served both the RACV and our clients who were insured with them with services that do not suffer from interruption, confusion or delaying tactics. In 2003 RACV implemented a preferred repairer scheme and invited Delphic Cove Pty Ltd to participate. After reviewing the agreement and obtaining expert industry and legal advice, we chose not to be contractually bound to the RACV. MAIN COMMITTEE The consequences of this action have had adverse consequences for our clients. They have been threatened and inconvenienced in the following ways as set out in the table shown below. The table also sets out realistic times and conditions which clients should enjoy, in the absence of the tactics used by RACV to dissuade clients from exercising their right to freedom of choice. The table then describes the process in the cash settlement situation. Someone lodges a claim. Realistically that would be processed in about five minutes; with RACV it is a half-hour process. A book assessment process should be immediate; the RACV tactic is to take two weeks. An authority to proceed should generally involve no delay but it takes two weeks under the RACV. In a realistic situation, payment should take three days but it takes six weeks under the RACV. In a realistic situation a warranty should be for a lifetime, but under the RACV it is nil. There are also provisions for policy cancellation and other issues in terms of the individual I have just been referring to. Another assessment was carried out by Gerry Raleigh from Kerry Panels. Gerry is a person whom I regard as a person of integrity. He has been attempting to raise these issues of the abuse of market power for some time. He has asked me to read his statement to the House: The cash settling process used by RACV is nothing more than a spiteful effort to make those repairers who do not wish to sign an RACV contract conform. Cash settling by RACV means the consumer is inconvenienced, he will have to arrange the repairs himself, no warranty is offered by the Insurer, he must wait until he receives a cheque and then proceed with repairs. If his vehicle is not driveable then naturally he would probably buckle and use the RACV repairer. A repairer can have a working relationship with RACV for 20 years, but with the introduction of the RACV repairer contract if the body shop does not conform, a wedge is driven between himself and his customer. And that has happened time after time with this particular smash repairer. This person uses some fairly colourful language here and I read this advisedly: The RACV repairer contracts are akin to a Mafia protection racket, in other words we offer you nothing but if you do not sign we will make life very difficult for you. These are not my words. These are his words; the words of a small business person who has been subjected to this abuse of market power. He went on to say: A common practice is for the consumer who stands by his independent repairer to have his policy cancelled. Those are two incidents, and I have one more document that I need to read to the House. This document is important and it is from LP Bodyworks. The person who runs the business says: In these years of operating our business we have acquired quite a substantial customer base, for these reasons we have always tried to work with our industry affiliates such as the Insurance Sector. This is why I would like to express my concerns with some issues, in regards to the way “RACV” as we know is underwritten ... is conducting itself when they implement their “Cash Settling” process with, what they call their “Non Accredited” shops. I would like to make the forum aware that we have been affiliated with RACV in the past and ongoing processes for the last 10 years, but for obvious reasons we stopped our relationship with them two years ago when they decided to revamp their Preferred Repairer Network (PSR). We found that the way this particular Insurer was trying to influence or control the repairer processes, was not keeping the customer’s and the repairer’s views in mind, but simply at cost not quality and most importantly “safety and manufacturers specifications” when it comes to reinstating the consumer’s vehicle. MAIN COMMITTEE And that is a concern. It continues: This method that the RACV has imposed is nothing more than a ploy to inconvenience and use the customer as a lever hold on the repairer, hoping that they will give in to the pressure and steer them through their own repair networks. That is the third small business. There are many more incidents and there are many more complaints that I have received about the RACV and that cash settling process. Clearly this is abuse of market power and it is something that should be investigated. I note that the ACCC’s Graeme Samuel has said recently that they want to be notified if there are any big businesses using standover tactics, and they are looking at utilising section 51AC of the Trade Practices Act. I am going to suggest that these small businesses start writing to the ACCC. Unfortunately, these small businesses have been saying that they have been raising their concerns with the ACCC and that no action has been taken. But I will be asking each of those people to make submissions to ACCC Chairman Samuel on the basis of the comments that he has been reported to have made in the media. Another issue with respect to the practice of insurance companies is colloquially called a ‘cut and shut’ operation. What does cut and shut mean? There are many cute names and technical terms, but it effectively means that if a car is totalled, if a car suffers extensive damage, if a car-like in the incident that I am about to report-has been half smashed away, the car is cut in half and half a different car of a similar model is basically welded onto it. I would like to talk about the case of a Holden Berlina which was owned by Mrs Sharon Hooper. In May 2004 the car was smashed into from behind and was extensively damaged. It was insured for the value of just over $17,000. It was probably overinsured, but the premiums the Hoopers had been paying for a number of years had been paid on the basis that the car’s value was $17,000. Its actual assessment value would have been less than that. When the car was taken to the RACV’s preferred smash repairer, an extensive quotation was given-it was in the order of $8,000-but the owner and the owner’s husband, Mr Richard Hooper, were basically saying: ‘This car has been totalled. It has been written off. We do not understand why you are attempting to repair this, it is in such a bad state.’ The insurer, RACV, insisted on the car being repaired. The car was repaired. But when Mr Hooper walked in to see what was happening with the car, he noticed that it had been cut in half. He was not even told that this was what was going to happen with the vehicle. When he walked into the premises of the approved smash repairer that had been referred by the RACV, he was told it was a ‘cut and shut’ repair. Mr Hooper picked up the vehicle but, after a short period driving it he realised that it was handling poorly and that the driver’s seat felt different. There is an extensive list of faults, with 31 faults being listed. He took the car back and said, ‘This car is not functioning properly,’ and that he wanted a proper, independent assessment. He left the car there. When he came back to see the progress being made, he found them trying to fix those very faults that he identified. He then demanded, legally, that an independent assessment be conducted. I have a list of 31 faults. It is absolutely extraordinary. The fuel tank was incorrectly fitted. The fuel lines were not appropriately secured. So this car was in fact a death trap. Seatbelts were distorted. The front seatbelts were incorrectly fitted. The fuel lines were incorrectly fitted. The vehicle was driving around right-hand turns; it was on an automatic right-hand turn. This car MAIN COMMITTEE should have been written off. The insurance company should have had the integrity to have had this car written off. These cut and shut practices, not appropriately supervised, are a way for the insurance companies to cut costs. I will say to the RACV and other insurance companies: if you are going to keep on doing this, I am going to keep on raising it in parliament until you get it right. Stop screwing small independent business holders and start acting appropriately or I will urge the Treasurer, in considering the report from the Productivity Commission, to take the appropriate action and make a mandatory code of conduct. and Resources) (5.10 pm)-I rise this afternoon to add my voice to the debate on the appropriation bills and to proudly associate myself with the achievements of this government, particularly economic achievements, over the past 10 budgets that we have had responsibility for. This year is no different. There is an $8.9 billion surplus-the eighth surplus since we have been in government. The unemployment rate is at its lowest level in some 28 years and we are delivering some $21.7 billion worth of tax cuts to the Australian people over the next four years. This is on top of the $14.7 billion worth of tax cuts provided in last year’s budget. Another very significant point in this budget is the fact that we have now paid off $90 billion of debt that we inherited when we came to office in 1996. To put that in simple terms, in 1996 we were faced with the challenge of having to find $9.6 billion out of tax funds just to pay the interest on the accumulated debt that we walked into in 1996, before a cent could be paid towards any services to the Australian people. We are now in the situation for the next financial year of having reduced that debt to less than $6 billion, which of course means that we will have in excess of $9 billion in additional funds available to spend on the Australian people. Of course, the more debt we pay off, the more we can commit to other things-it is not rocket science. As the Treasurer said, this is not by accident. It certainly was not a fluke. This is an outcome of very sound economic management. The budget has been extremely generous to my electorate of Leichhardt. I certainly appreciate the contribution to a number of projects, including the ongoing flood proofing of the Bruce Highway at Tully, south of Cairns. There was an additional $2.9 million to assist the state government in their planning works for this program. There was $1.5 million allocated last year to get these works underway and to prioritise them. Unfortunately, the state government have continued to drag their feet. The planning work was supposed to be completed next month for the work to be finished in 2006-07, but we have now discovered that the state government has not been able to achieve this outcome. We have allocated another $2.9 million to see if that can help light a fire under the state government planning authorities to get something done there. It is certainly a serious economic and social impediment in Far North Queensland. Unfortunately, even at this stage we are probably looking at 2008-09, if they actually get their act together, to get it to completion. I have to say that sending the shadow minister from Victoria up there to become a poor apologist for the state government did not do anything for achieving this outcome. I think he would do a lot better if he were to encourage his state government colleagues to start to do some work rather than make excuses for not doing it. Russett Park was another good example of a commitment from this government. Half a million dollars was committed to the Russett Park community and to the Mareeba Shire MAIN COMMITTEE
