speaker: Mr Entsch (Leichhardt
theText: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, TourismCouncil to put a three-metre causeway across a river. For many years the community, which is only about 15 to 20 kilometres from Cairns, has been stranded by that river. Unfortunately that river has taken two lives to date. In spite of a lot of huff and puff from the state government, with the money committed from the local residents, the council and the federal government, people will be able to drive onto a three-metre causeway. However, because of the state government’s reluctance to contribute, there will be quite a significant fall off one end because it is not going to be quite completed, and that is the legacy of the state government. I encourage the council and the residents to go ahead and do what they can to get as much of this completed as they can because, at the end of the day, if another life is lost in another wet season that will be squarely on the shoulders of the Labor state government. The Roads to Recovery program is another very successful one. In my electorate Cairns City Council will receive another $1 million-plus. There will be $700,000 for Cook Shire, a very large electorate; $166,000 for Douglas Shire; and $93,000 for Torres Strait. Since the Roads to Recovery program has come in the amount of bitumen that has been laid by local authorities is amazing. The money is going straight through to these local authorities and they are able to prioritise their work, keep their work force on the job-certainly not allowing anything to be cost-shifted back into the state government coffers-and you can certainly see the results. A good example of that was the opportunity I had the other day to open the new works at Aumuller Road, a four-lane highway. That work had been well overdue. Concrete slabs were laid by the American troops in the 1939-45 war and of course in the period since then the road has deteriorated significantly. The Roads to Recovery funding has allowed the Cairns City Council to upgrade this road to an excellent piece of infrastructure. The other thing in the budget which I was looking for and was very pleased to see was the additional $90 million in the black spot funding program. Again, this has provided vital funding in regional areas and, in my view, it has saved a lot of lives. You only have to drive on any of the highways in Cairns and outlying areas to see outstanding examples of work carried out under this program-work that certainly would not have been done if we were waiting for the state government to put their hands in their pockets. Another very successful funding achievement was $10 million for the Cairns Esplanade. This is on top of a $9 million spend that we had about three years ago, taking the total Australian government investment to some $19 million. The results of the work so far have been quite profound and not only for visitors to Cairns-although 40 per cent of its economy is reliant on tourism, and it is the second biggest international tourism destination to Sydney. The work that has been done on this esplanade area has certainly added to the experience of locals as well as to that of international visitors. It is amazing to see the number of locals who have come to love and enjoy this area. The additional $10 million is going to be able to finish the whole waterfront area of Cairns City and it certainly will make a huge difference to that area. Then there were the unsuccessful bids by the reef and rain forest CRCs last year. I remember that Senator McLucas was on her knees praying every night that they were going to fail, that they were never going to run, because that would give her something to criticise. She makes no effort whatsoever to get off her butt and do something about seeing if she can find MAIN COMMITTEE an alternative. Instead, she uses political opportunism just to criticise or knock for the sake of knocking to try to build her own political stakes. But there are those in the community who realise that the bids that were put in by both of those entities were not appropriate-that they did not fit the criteria-and they are prepared to work with me to find an alternative. Again, I would like to recognise the outstanding contribution of Russell Reichelt, CEO of the Reef CRC; Daniel Gschwind, CEO of the Queensland Tourism Industry Council; and John McIntyre, who was with TTNQ. Rather than criticise and make cheap political shots, as happened with Senator McLucas, they realised that there were problems and that we had to do something different, and they sat down and worked with me. As a direct result of the contribution of those three outstanding citizens, we now have the Marine and Tropical Sciences Research Facility for Far North Queensland, which has been funded with significantly more resources than both the reef and rainforest CRCs combined. There has been some $40 million to establish this magnificent, world-first facility-it will be the best in the world-in both Cairns and Townsville. It will be the premium facility in the world for reef and rainforest research. It will certainly attract a lot of interest from both the conservation and scientific communities around the world. James Cook University have been very excited by this, because it gives them another opportunity in relation to expanding options that are available through their campuses. This is on top of a veterinary school. A few years ago we announced a medical school for James Cook University-again, provided through good economic management by this government and strong lobbying by me-and the member for Herbert, Peter Lindsay, played a very significant role in achieving that. So we had the medical school, and now we have a veterinary school-and the funding has been set aside for that. Of course, the vicechancellor of James Cook University is very excited about the opportunities this will provide and some very significant and unique strengths and attributes will enhance the delivery of services of James Cook University. Another issue that has been of concern in my area-and, again, it has been addressed through this budget-is illegal fishing, particularly in the gulf and Torres Strait. Some 87 illegal fishing vessels were apprehended in northern waters this year alone, and we had to look seriously at dealing with the vessels that were impounded and held in the harbour, which was totally unsatisfactory. Residents on Thursday Island and Horn Island had concerns with regard to health problems and security. But $32.5 million has been set aside for the detection, detention and prosecution of illegal fishermen. A very significant amount of money has been set aside to build a purpose-built, 48-person facility on Horn Island to immediately process illegal fishermen with regard to their health et cetera and send them off to Darwin for prosecution. There will also be a purpose-built facility for the destruction of vessels that are taken in the area. That can be done in a way that is not going to cause any environmental problems. That will provide a significant number of jobs for local residents on Horn Island and Thursday Island, something that has been very much welcomed by that community. Given that, particularly in the Torres Strait, fishing is the only natural resource, other than tourism opportunities, it is absolutely imperative that we do everything we can to protect the integrity of that resource. We are also enhancing search and rescue in Far North Queensland. Some $54.7 million has been allocated out of this budget for the establishment of a new search and rescue service. MAIN COMMITTEE There will be four turboprop aircraft, which are much faster than anything that is available now. Three will be flying at all times. One, I would expect, will be based in Far North Queensland-in Cairns, I expect. These are very high-speed purpose-built aircraft for search and rescue. Instead of taking Coastwatch off task to look for people who are lost in this vast area, these aircraft will be readily available. They will be fitted with the latest technology, including surface search radars and forward-looking infrared equipment, which will allow them to work at night time, and satellite communications, again offering another level of support and safety in our region. A range of other initiatives has also been made available through this budget. They are national initiatives, certainly, but they are initiatives that are going to be of great benefit in my electorate. There is $179 million for new Indigenous health measures. We know of the work that needs to be done there. There is an additional $40 million for primary health clinics in communities. There is over $102 million over four years to improve the health of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander mothers, babies and children and to reduce the impact of chronic diseases. There is $8 million to help deal with issues of petrol sniffing. There is also funding of some $10 million for government hearing services for Indigenous communities, and funding to help communities keep professional staff through an extension of the fringe benefits tax supplementation program for an additional four years. There is funding for bowel cancer. The prevalence of cancer touches all of us in the community. There is some $43.4 million for the national bowel cancer screening program and another $23.1 million over four years to help local groups and care providers offer better support for cancer patients and their families. This new funding will be used to fit out and equip premises for palliative care, pastoral care, counselling and family support. There is also $25 million to assist in tackling problems with young people who are starting to smoke at an early agethey have got to start at the source, particularly in relation to lung cancer. There has been additional funding for mental health, which is an issue I raise regularly in this place. There is some $69 million for youth mental health initiatives, appreciating that three-quarters of mental health problems begin before the age of 25. There is another $39.6 million for the national depression initiative, money certainly well spent and a direct result of responsible economic management by this government. Diabetes initiatives will also receive a boost of some $44.2 million and asthma will receive another $27.1 million. All in all, it has been an outstanding contribution to these areas. Another area which has caused some difficulty for the other side of politics, for the Labor Party, is the tax cuts, with the reduction from 17 to 15 per cent for our lower income earners and the lifting of the thresholds which has been quite significant. You always hear complaints, particularly from the other side, about the brain drain, about our intelligent young people moving overseas because of the high tax problems here. We are losing all those young people. What we have done is bring our tax system into line with those countries that attract these young professionals. It will mean that there is no longer a reason for them to travel overseas. I would have thought that the Labor Party would have offered congratulations, particularly given the skills shortages that we have in this country at the moment and our desperate need to retain those young highly skilled people. But, no, purely for the sake of politics they are out there jumping up and down, threatening to disallow this and coming back with a plagiarised mickey mouse alternative. From talking to my own business community, I know that there is a MAIN COMMITTEE lot of confusion out there. They desperately want this to be introduced on 1 July. We have got to call on the Leader of the Opposition to stop blocking this, stop playing havoc with the employees in Far North Queensland and stop threatening to block these tax cuts. At the end of the day, all he is going to do is cause an unnecessary cost to business. I ask him to stop the nonsense and allow the tax cuts to go through. (Time expired) fend Western Australia. It seems to me that the federal Treasurer and Liberal leadership hopeful Peter Costello wants to base his leadership push on proving just how well he can bully the states. The Treasurer’s recent attack on Western Australia is incredible and his threat to withhold GST revenues from that state is state bashing at its pitiful worse. The Treasurer has threatened to withhold GST revenues from WA unless WA drops more state taxes. It is interesting that the Treasurer would do this because on the one hand the government are saying that this is not a Commonwealth tax but a state tax, yet on the other hand it is a tax they want to control when it suits them. The other interesting thing is that it was a Liberal Premier who signed WA up to the GST. Because of the Treasurer’s threats, I went to the current Premier’s web site. I was very pleased to discover the following information, which I want to quote: In 1999 the then Premier Richard Court signed an agreement on behalf of Western Australia to receive a share of the GST revenue in return for abolishing three state taxes and reviewing a further six. Indeed, since 1999, as part of that agreement signed by Premier Court, WA has abolished three state taxes. It has abolished financial institutions duty and listed marketable securities duty, and debits tax is legislated to be abolished on 1 July 2005. WA has reviewed the other six and abolished three more taxes. It has abolished unlisted marketable securities duty, leases duty and cheque duty. Western Australia also abolished a further two taxes not listed on that agreement: stamp duty on workers compensation insurance and stamp duty on life insurance. In total, the WA state government has abolished eight state taxes, while the agreement only required the abolition of three state taxes. While the GST was signed up under the previous Liberal state government, the incoming Labor government has met those commitments, and I think the Premier’s claim that Western Australia has not only honoured its side of the agreement but exceeded it is demonstrably true. I also want to point out to the Treasurer-Australia’s next Leader of the Opposition-that my home state of WA contributes $2 billion more each year than we get back in federal funding. That is a $1,000 subsidy by every man, woman and child in Western Australia to the rest of the nation. In addition, up to 90 per cent of the royalties Western Australia receives from its resources are distributed to other states, yet the federal government refuses to adequately fund the necessary infrastructure required for mining and other resource development. Indeed, ABS figures show that the Commonwealth tax take is $10,462 per person, while just $2,503 per person is derived from state based revenue. I am grateful to the Premier’s office in WA for the above information. Something else that I have been pointing out in Western Australia for years is that in WA we are free from the plague of poker machines-and we thank successive governments for that. I would certainly call on future state governments in Western Australia to continue with that no pokies policy. We need to remind the federal Treasurer that we do not, unlike other states, derive income from those machines. Indeed, it is worth pointing out that New South Wales derives $1.311 MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Appropriation Bill No 2 2005 2006 Appropriation Parliamentary Departments Bill No 1 2005 2006 Appropriation Bill No 5 2004 2005 Appropriation Bill No 6 2004 2005

speaker: Mr Edwards (Cowan) (5.30 Pm)
theText: In speaking on the appropriation bills I want to debillion from gambling and Victoria $1.324 billion. That puts WA behind the eight ball right from the word go. But I would rather have it that way than to allow Treasurer Costello to force poker machines into our state. They are not wanted and they are not required-and I think that is pretty well a bipartisan position in Western Australia. The other taxable revenue device we do not have in WA is road tollways. I am not sure what revenue is derived from road tollways, but it seems to me that this is becoming more and more a means of revenue in New South Wales and Victoria. I to say the Treasurer: ‘Thank you very much, but, just like poker machines, we don’t want any road tollways in Western Australia either.’ I also noticed that the WA government in last week’s state budget scrapped the bank debits tax, freed up some 24,000 people from paying land tax, raised land tax thresholds and cut the middle land tax while abolishing stamp duty on mortgage refinancing for owner-occupiers and small business. Overall in WA the state government is returning some $870 million in tax relief over the next four years. This is on top of the $1.5 billion in tax cuts announced last year. In WA, the Gallop government is delivering $2.4 billion in tax and family relief. In addition, it is putting more investment into training teachers, building new schools, providing more police, generating more electricity and expanding and building new hospitals. At the same time, in partnership with the resource sector, it is investing in new infrastructure. Infrastructure is something the Howard-Costello government refuses to accept a fair responsibility for in WA, let alone show any responsibility for. On the one hand the HowardCostello government is refusing to assist with infrastructure and resource development, but at the same time it wants to reduce state revenue and is saying to WA, ‘We want you to generate more income so we can confiscate that for Canberra.’ It is pretty obvious that both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, who both come from the eastern states-and I am not saying there is anything wrong with that-have little knowledge and appreciation of the fact that it is wellrun and well-managed states like Western Australia that are hand in hand with the resource sector developing our nation, expanding our exports and building our economy. The Treasurer should get off the back of WA and get out of its path. He should stop being an impediment to Western Australia’s development and for a change he should support our state and our crucial resource sector. Mr Deputy Speaker, you would well know that prices of minerals fluctuate-there are peaks and troughs. There is no guarantee in the future that the prices you are getting today will be there in five, six or seven years time. Any state government which cut its funding and by so doing inhibited its ability to work hand-in-hand with the resource sector to explore and develop new prospects, fields or mining areas would be cutting the throat of the state in the long term. My advice to the Treasurer is that he ought to give WA a fair go. He should not be the goose that kills the state that lays Australia’s richest golden egg. If Western Australia allowed itself to be bullied by this Treasurer, this Prime Minister and this government, not only would we be killing the goose that lays Australia’s richest golden egg, but in view of the figures that I gave a little while ago-and in view of the revenue which is generated in Western Australia and distributed to other parts of the nation-we would be doing a great disservice to this nation. So the state government, with the support of all federal members, Liberal and Labor, should stand up to this Costello-Howard government and support the Premier of Western Australia. If they do not, they are turning their backs on the people of that great state. MAIN COMMITTEE Having exposed the Treasurer for the reckless person that he is, particularly in relation to Western Australia, I have a number of other issues that I want to deal with. I want to turn tonight to another issue to do with the Minister for Veterans’ Affairs. I call on this minister to fix the incredible debacle which surrounds the issuing of military medals in Australia. We recently saw the very embarrassing situation our nation found itself in when the president of Indonesia awarded that nation’s humanitarian medal to the nine Australians killed in the Sea King disaster. It was an embarrassment to Australia-not that the medal was awarded but that we had nothing that we could give. It was a very emotional moment for most Australians when they saw those coffins coming back with the medals from Indonesia, and they were matched by a sprig of wattle, I think at the suggestion of the Governor General. The government moved fairly quickly to arrange for our own humanitarian medal to be awarded to those people who were so tragically killed. They did that with this opposition’s support, and I think it was a fair and reasonable thing for them to do. But it is interesting in this context to remember that, some 11 months ago, the government announced a new Australian Defence Force medal, and they said applications for this medal would be called for by the end of last year. Interestingly, that announcement was made as a lead-up to the last election. Where have the medals gone? We have no idea where they are, what their design is, when they will be available, and what the criteria for these medals will be. That is despite this government having promised on more than one occasion that applications would be called for at the end of last year. Labor’s policy is very clear in this area. We announced it last year, and we have stood by that policy. We would award the Australian Defence Force medal to volunteers who have served their initial period of enlistment of three years or in some circumstances two years. You might remember back to the post Second World War era when some people who served in Korea only had to enlist for two years. We would also award the medal to next of kin of those killed on duty or to those who were forced to take discharge because of injury, or in the case of women because of situations where they were forced out because of marriage or pregnancy. A number of women served in the ADF for a period of four years or signed up for four years. Some of them had to get out because they were married or having a child. We would want to recognise the contribution that those women made. I believe that this government has made a farce of these new medals, and it is really high time that it got the house in order. But it does not end there. In July 2002 I, along with several other members of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, visited our troops on the ground in the Middle East. Included in that was a visit to our SAS blokes in Bagram. While we were there we gave a commitment, as much as a group of members of parliament can give a commitment, to pursue the issue of a campaign medal to recognise the wonderful service that those people were contributing in that country. Indeed when we returned to Australia the committee wrote to the Minister for Defence seeking the government’s commitment to such a campaign medal. Last year the minister announced the medal and gave the impression to recipients that it would be available for them to have by ANZAC Day this year. Not only has the Afghanistan campaign medal failed to materialise but there is now a story which causes some concern to me, and that is that the medals, yet to be manufactured, will be further delayed because the MAIN COMMITTEE government is considering having them minted overseas. I do not want to divert from the real case, which is the fact that these people are entitled to their medals. But I do think that the minister should, if she is going to allow these medals to be minted overseas, be prepared to defend that decision, because there will be a fair amount of angst in Australia if that is the case. The real story here is that recognition delayed is recognition denied. In my view, and I know in the view of many former and current serving soldiers, the length of time they have had to wait for these medals is a fair reflection of the lack of appreciation that this government really has for the job that these blokes and these women did. The individual and personal challenges and dangers that these members of the ADF, as soldiers operating in difficult terrain, had to expose themselves to and the dangers of the elements as well as the enemy are exactly what campaign medals are designed to reflect. SoI am going to pose the question: why are our Afghanistan veterans who were serving that country in 2002 and the Iraq veterans still waiting for their campaign medals so many years after the campaign, particularly in relation to the Afghanistan campaign? I think it would be very difficult for any member of this parliament to justify such a delay. As I said, recognition delayed is recognition denied. I want to call on the minister to demand some action here and to demand it now. These blokes are entitled to their medals. They should have them. strong economic growth, the continuing high employment, the continuing low interest rates and low inflation and the record highs in consumer and business confidence are all due in no small way to the policies of the Howard government. In bringing down his 10th budget just three weeks ago the Treasurer called it a budget framed for the future. It was a budget framed for the future, a budget focused on future opportunities for our young people, a budget focused on care for our aged, a budget focused on the continued security of our nation, a budget focused on the health services that our citizens will need in the future, a budget focused on the continued strong economic growth of our nation that is synonymous with the Howard government. The coalition government, under the leadership of John Howard, have a great deal of experience under our belt. Our win at the last federal election has given us a unique opportunity of ensuring that the next three years of policy decisions really count. The agenda for Australia’s future has to be cemented further, given our ageing population. Level-headedness, maturity, common sense and sound decision making are going to be needed more than ever over the next three years. The recent budget sets a blueprint for the next 12 months and lays the foundation for the fourth-term agenda of the Howard government. There has been a lot of talk about the future. Without continued strong economic growth, our future as a country and for our people would not be in the position it is in today. The Australian economy has performed impressively and that is not by accident. It has performed impressively because of sound economic management and a commitment to ongoing reform and policy decisions that have been taken by the Howard government. What does this budget mean to the people I represent in the federal parliament, the people of McPherson? What does it mean to our communities on the southern Gold Coast? How have we benefited and what will those continued benefits mean in the future to our young people, MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Appropriation Bill No 2 2005 2006 Appropriation Parliamentary Departments Bill No 1 2005 2006 Appropriation Bill No 5 2004 2005 Appropriation Bill No 6 2004 2005

speaker: Mrs May (Mcpherson) (5.49 Pm)
theText: The future prosperity of Australia, the continuingour young families, our aged and our city as it continues to grow at a rate unmatched anywhere else in Australia? Because of our prudent management of the Australian economy, the government will deliver further personal income tax cuts to all Australians. We are a government that believe in giving Australian taxpayers back their hard earned dollars with a budget surplus. It is now up to the opposition to pass on those tax cuts and to allow Australians to benefit from these tax cuts from 1 July. I say to the opposition: don’t penalise the Australian taxpayer by blocking this legislation. Vote with us and pass on the tax cuts. Under the proposed legislation, further personal income tax cuts are worth $21.7 billion over the next four years. These are tax cuts that will assist low-income earners, boost disposable incomes and reward participation and hard work. Australians will keep more of what they earn, and why shouldn’t they? There are now more incentives for Aussies to continue to work hard and reap the rewards of that hard work. With the support of the opposition, from 1 July this year the 17 per cent marginal tax rate will be cut to 15 per cent, and the 42 per cent tax threshold will increase from $58,000 to $63,000 on 1 July 2005 and to $70,000 on 1 July 2006. From1 July 2005, the 47 per cent threshold will increase from $70,000 to $95,000 and on 1 July 2006 it will increase again to $125,000. In my view, these tax cuts and increases in thresholds are fair and well targeted. These changes ensure that more than 80 per cent of taxpayers face a top marginal income tax rate of 30 per cent or less over the forward estimates period, and from 1 July 2006 the top marginal rate will apply to only three per cent of taxpayers. In addition to the income tax cuts and the government’s ongoing plan to encourage people to save for their retirement, the superannuation surcharge will be scrapped altogether from 1 July 2005. The cut in the lowest rate of tax benefits also benefits seniors and means that senior Australians eligible for the senior Australian tax offset will now pay no tax on their annual income up to $21,968 for a single and on equal incomes up to a joint $36,494 for a couple. Once again I say to the opposition: pass the tax cuts. Allow all Australians to benefit from the personal income tax cuts from 1 July 2005. Australians should share in the prosperity of our nation and the economic benefits that have flowed from our strong economic management. I say to the opposition: act responsibly and pass the tax cuts. One of the most significant achievements of this government has been the continuing fall in unemployment rates. McPherson’s December unemployment rate hit a historical low of 5.2 per cent compared to the then national average of 5.5 per cent. It was the first time our unemployment rate was better than the national average. In the past McPherson has trailed somewhere between two and three per cent behind the national average. These figures were welcome news for the southern Gold Coast. It meant that more people had jobs and that young people had job opportunities. The results reflect the Howard government’s strong economic management once again and highlight the significant labour market improvements that are achievable when a government is prepared to reform the employment services market through the Job Network and make the hard decisions on workplace reform. Despite the fact that more Australians are in work today and that the unemployment rate has fallen to a low unmatched for 28 years, it is more important than ever that the opposition support the government’s workplace relations and work force participation reforms, which have the potential to make even further inroads into the level of unemployment. Another chalMAIN COMMITTEE lenge for the opposition is to support key reforms in the areas of increasing work force participation and in the labour market. Part of the challenge for government in securing our future is increasing participation in the work force. Our 14 consecutive years of growth have been accompanied by low unemployment rates, low inflation rates and low interest rates but the future will see Australia come under increasing pressure as it competes in a freer global market environment, where competition will be aggressive, not just for our natural resources, manufactured goods and services but importantly for our greatest asset, our labour force. Participation in the work force, assisting people from welfare to work, is much more than statistics about unemployment rates. It is about people becoming financially secure and sharing in the wealth of this country. In many cases it is about people’s self-esteem and confidence. It is about people overcoming their social isolation. It is about recognising the value of a person’s contribution to our society. It is about people feeling worthwhile about contributing. As a government we have a responsibility to ensure all Australians who want to work and who are able to work are given the opportunity to participate. We have to ensure that there are programs that will assist in training and skilling people so that they can become productive members of our society. It is about assisting people from welfare to work. It is not about paying people a benefit every fortnight and forgetting about them. We have a responsibility to engage those people who are able to and want to work. It is about providing rehabilitation services and education and training opportunities that will give these people the best chance ever of participating. Employers will also be encouraged to employ people with disabilities. Schemes will be expanded to assist employers to take on these people. We will work with industry to identify the skill shortages and ensure we address those skill shortages with the appropriate training programs. We need to encourage as many people of working age as we can to join our work force, to become productive members of our communities. During the last federal campaign our government announced a commitment to 24 technical colleges to be built in regions around Australia. The Gold Coast has been identified as an area to receive funding for such a college. This election commitment provides for the establishment and operation of colleges for year 11 and 12 students to promote excellence in the teaching and acquiring of trade and craft skills at the secondary school level. Each college will be linked to and endorsed by industry and run autonomously by principals who will be able to engage teaching staff on a performance pay basis. We know today that one of the greatest challenges for business is finding people to take up skilled jobs. For too long success for young Australians has been equated to finishing year 12 and obtaining a university degree. This, of course, is a path that many young people aspire to and a path that should be supported. However, there is an attitude in the community that only a university degree will secure employment. In many cases it has become a status symbol and as a country we have paid a significant economic and social cost for this attitude. One-third of students who start university will not finish their studies. As a country we are facing critical skill shortages in the trades, including building and construction, metals, manufacturing and automotive. On the Gold Coast we are also facing shortages in the hospitality industry. We desperately need young people to take on traineeships or apprenticeships as chefs. We need people in this industry, both front of house and back of MAIN COMMITTEE house. People need to be well trained and willing to work in this multimillion dollar industry, which supports our very strong tourism industry. This government is committed to revolutionising vocational education and training, through the 24 colleges. As a nation, we should value trades training as highly as any other form of postsecondary education. I look forward to the Gold Coast technical college becoming a reality and offering choices and another education pathway to the young people on the Gold Coast. I know a number of tenders have been presented from the Gold Coast. I wish each of the consortiums every success with their bids and of course look forward to working with the successful consortium in establishing the Gold Coast Australian technical college. Small business, as we know, is the backbone of the Australian economy. Businesses have been growing. They have had to become smarter. They are now part of opportunities in a growing global market that has become increasingly competitive. We need to ensure that our businesses are as productive and competitive as they can be, and that means we need to address impediments to business activity. There is an increasing need for industrial relations reform to increase work force participation. Legislation such as the fair dismissal bill will assist business in employing those extra people they need. The Treasurer announced $1.8 billion of tax cuts to enhance the competitiveness of Australian businesses. Already abolished is the three per cent tariff on imported business inputs which do not have substitutes manufactured in Australia. This will be a saving to business of $1.3 billion over the next five years. The tourism industry on the Gold Coast is made up of thousands of small businesses, and our tourism industry will be a winner from the extra $453 million being invested into attracting tourists to our country. Our local communities will benefit from the extra $7.5 million that will be spent on promoting tourism projects and encouraging visitors to stay on the Gold Coast longer, through the Australian Tourism Development Program. Tourism is big business for our local communities, and the Gold Coast is no exception. The industry provides thousands of jobs throughout Australia, and by boosting tourism in local areas extra jobs can be created and additional income earned by small businesses. I encourage all members and senators to take a trip north to Australia’s tourism capital. Everyone deserves the chance to experience our unique way of life, to take part in a fresh Gold Coast adventure that stretches from historic rural communities in the north to border towns and coastal centres on the southern Gold Coast, and to enjoy our beautiful hinterland-the green behind the gold-and our pristine beaches. We have it all. There have been many discussions over a number of years about the future of our great country-the future of our ageing population, the future of our environment, the future of our health system and, importantly, the future infrastructure plans for our road and rail systems. Through AusLink, many of these infrastructure plans will be funded. With this budget, an additional $150 million over five years will be provided to expand the Roads to Recovery program, and an additional $90 million will be provided to continue the Road Safety Black Spot Program. The Gold Coast City Council will benefit from these funds. An additional $14 million will be provided to the council for the Roads to Recovery program. There is no doubt that this funding is urgently needed on the Gold Coast to address the serious traffic problems we are MAIN COMMITTEE encountering due to our rapid population growth. I know the council will also be applying for funding under the Road Safety Black Spot Program, which has been a successful initiative in the past. The establishment of the future fund is also a very welcome announcement. There is no doubt that we need to make provision for the future. We need to begin saving for the future to meet the costs of our ageing population. The future fund will be an independent fund with a statutory board of eminent people who are going to make an investment on behalf of Australia’s future. It will be a large fund and it is expected to accumulate earnings over a period of time, which will mean that the government can fund its liabilities and relieve future generations of the costs of the ageing of the population. These earnings will be safeguarded by legislation. The future fund will only invest in infrastructure projects that make commercial sense. The government expects the fund to be able to invest in listed infrastructure vehicles and listed property trusts. There will not be uncommercial, risky investments being made by the future fund that would risk the capacity for government to pay the superannuation liabilities. Since coming to power in 1996, the Howard government has managed to retire most of the $96 billion debt we inherited on coming to office. By reducing this debt, we can look to the future with confidence. We can be assured that our commitments, as a government, to all Australians will be met. The savings by government from the reduction of the debt will ensure that the future fund will meet the needs of our nation in the long term. There are many good news stories in this budget-for example, a one-off lump sum payment this year of $1,000 to eligible carers receiving the carer payment and $600 to those receiving the carers allowance. Carers in our community should never be taken for granted. They undertake a selfless task, often a lonely task, isolated from society because of the very nature of the task they have undertaken. Cancer is an insidious disease. I have recently lost two very close friends to this disease and have a very dear friend who is currently fighting the disease-Wal is being very brave, but I worry about his fight. The government is committed to a major funding package to improve cancer care through bowel cancer screening, dedicated cancer research, the training of cancer nurses, increased funding for palliative care, and $5.5 million over two years to raise national awareness of skin cancer and encourage action to prevent it. Another important program is the commitment to a national youth campaign aimed at reducing the number of young people who take up smoking. We all know that smoking is a killer. Early intervention programs hopefully will have the desired effect. The government has committed $25 million over four years to help discourage young Australians from taking up smoking. The budget also makes dementia a national health priority. The $321 million package will enhance the quality of life of dementia sufferers and their carers. As life expectancy increases, dementia will become more common within our communities. The funding package will offer more opportunities for dementia-specific training for carers, community and residential care workers, and people working in services such as the police, transport and emergency services. I particularly commend this initiative by the government. Dementia is a debilitating disease. Sufferers and their carers face huge challenges on a daily basis, and any help and assistance will be welcome, I know. Diabetes is also becoming a huge national health concern. The government has provided $44.2 million over four years to continue a national approach to improve the prevention and MAIN COMMITTEE management of diabetes. There is no doubt that education on the effects of diabetes, and programs to assist Australians to recognise early warning signs, are positive steps in bringing diabetes under control. Balancing work and family and the daily stresses of life can have huge impacts on families. Often families need outside counselling to help keep relationships and families together. The government has announced funding over four years to establish a network of 65 family relationship centres across Australia. These centres will help couples access premarriage education and assist families experiencing relationship difficulties with information and access to family skills training and support that can be delivered through other departments and agencies. This initiative is another example of government support for and recognition of the importance of strong family relationships within our communities. Strong families build strong communities and ultimately a strong country. The Prime Minister has often referred to Australia as having a decent society, a tolerant society, a society that recognises and supports lowand middle-income families with dependent children. Through this budget, those families and children are being supported and encouraged now and for the future. I commend the bills to the House. Dr EMERSON (Rankin) (6.08 pm)-I would like to concentrate my remarks on the budget primarily upon an economic analysis of the budget and the wider economic implications that flow from it. Members of parliament will be well aware of Labor’s critique of the government’s spending program that began before the previous budget, carried through the 2004-05 budget and then flowed into the pre-election campaign period. That critique was that the budget spending spree amounted to $66 billion and would put undue pressure on interest rates. Labor did not come to this view belatedly but said it consistently as the government went upon this spending spree. There was only one purpose behind that spending spree, and that was to get the government re-elected. It was clear it was going to give total priority to that and then, after the election, worry about the economic consequences. After the election the chickens did come home to roost, as Labor had feared they would: the OECD, the IMF and the Reserve Bank of Australia all expressed concerns about the management of the economy, including in their critique the $66 billion spending spree. In March 2005 the Reserve Bank had no choice left to it but to increase interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point. The effect of the pre-election spending spree was to pour fuel onto the flames of already strong consumer spending. The government knew exactly what it was doing, but calculated correctly that it would be able to get away with it and deal with the consequences after the election. The interest rate rise itself has had an adverse impact on home borrowers. A quarter of a percentage point interest rate increase can be a significant increase when people are borrowed up to the hilt, as they are. If Labor’s critique of the pre-election spending spree of $66 billion was right, then surely a critique of a $103 billion spending spree would carry some weight. And that is, in fact, what the government has done in the 2005-06 budget-it has gone on a $103 billion spending spree. I have said consistently that I am concerned about the impact of this on further interest rate rises. The Reserve Bank’s task is quite straightforward-that is, to keep inflation within a nominated band. It is an independent Reserve Bank, that is its job, and if inflation increases beyond the upper limit of that band the Reserve Bank has little choice but to act. MAIN COMMITTEE The pre-election spending spree was 10.3 per cent in real terms in 2004, which was the fastest in more than 20 years. It is interesting to cast one’s mind back to when such a pre-election spending spree last occurred. It was, in fact, by the Fraser government, when John Howard was Treasurer of this country, when they sought in vain to get re-elected by making very large and expensive promises. It did not work in 1983 because Labor swept to power, but it has worked in the most recent election. But the problem is that the spending that is going on in this economy has been at such a rate that the capacity of the economy to supply the goods and services that are being demanded is now very limited. The government has failed to invest, in its nine years, in improving the capacity of the Australian economy to meet the demands associated with strong consumer spending. When strong consumer spending smashes up against a capacity constraint, it spills over in one of two ways-in Australia’s case, in both. The first is into imports. It is a matter of record that Australia now has recorded 41 successive trade deficits and record current account deficits, and the figures released today put the current account deficit at 7.25 per cent of GDP. This is a horrendously high level, far in excess of the level when Paul Keating warned of the dangers in the mid-1980s of Australia becoming a banana republic, and yet this government is completely complacent about a record current account deficit-a chronic current account deficitwhich, again, is feeding into Australia’s international debt. In 1995 when the government rolled out its debt truck, Australia’s international net debt was $180 billion. Today figures reveal that it has climbed to $425 billion, more than doubling since the time that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer promised to follow policies that would bring foreign debt down. At that time both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer warned that at some point-and they believe that point had been reached when debt was $180 billion-foreign lenders would apply a risk premium to the interest rate that they charge Australia for borrowing such large amounts of money. Again, the Prime Minister has been condemned by his own rhetoric, by his own belief. Now, with foreign debt at $425 billion, foreign lenders are definitely applying a premium, because Australia has the third-highest interest rates in the Western world. If that is not bad enough, we are now in a situation where we are at the peak of a commodity price cycle. Commodity prices can only go down from here. The Australian dollar is a commodity currency. If you track the movements in the Australian dollar with commodity prices you will find a very close correlation. As the commodity price cycle has peaked, the risk for the exchange rate is that it will depreciate. A depreciating exchange rate will increase the cost in Australian dollar terms of goods imported from overseas-and we have lots of goods imported from overseas as a result of the spending spree spilling over into imports. If that happens we have a new source of inflation in Australia through a depreciating exchange rate. In the last couple of years the prices of domestically produced goods have risen above the Reserve Bank’s range at which it would need to act to increase interest rates. But the impact of an appreciating dollar as the commodity price cycle has gone up has been that there has been an offset to domestic inflation from overseas such that the overall consumer price index has remained within the range. Therefore, with that one exception of March 2005, the Reserve Bank has not been forced to increase interest rates. But now that the government has failed to respond to the capacity constraints and has poured fuel onto the spending fire, the risk of a MAIN COMMITTEE depreciating currency means that those strong domestic price rises will not have an overseas offset but will be exacerbated by inflation from overseas. In those circumstances the Reserve Bank will have no choice but to increase interest rates. Recessions in this country have been caused essentially by the Reserve Bank acting too late to dampen spending and then having to put the brakes on too severely. That has caused recessions. The preconditions for a recession now exist in Australia. AmI saying that there will be a recession? I am not making that prediction, but I am saying that this government has substantially increased the risk of a recession. Ask BIS Shrapnel, who earlier in the week were forecasting mortgage interest rates of nine per cent. Mortgage interest rates of nine per cent would smash the Australian economy because of the very high levels of debt of most Australians who are trying to buy a home. One of the indicators of the state of the economy at the moment is that the unemployment rate is the lowest since 1976. That suggests a tight labour market-in fact, it is proof of a tight labour market. Another is that job vacancies are the highest in the 26-year history of job vacancies; again, pointing to a very tight labour market. There are labour shortages. Business is reporting labour shortages as a constraint on output. That particular indicator is the highest in the 15-year history of the survey. Capacity utilisation has just fallen away little, but from a 15year high. Interestingly, over the years I have found the survey of consumer sentiment to be a very important indicator. The survey of consumer sentiment had reached record levels and then, when the quarter of a percentage point interest rate rise came through, it fell away. But now that people have gotten used to that interest rate rise, consumer sentiment has gone up again. In parliament today the Treasurer said that the latest retail sales figures suggest that consumer spending has now perhaps peaked and is starting to moderate. But the retail sales figures were all adjusted as a result of the Australian Bureau of Statistics having another look at those figures, and they were all revised upwards in the previous month. So there is plenty of evidence around of capacity constraints and of strong consumer spending. In respect of the housing market, a fundamental cause of the very high house prices-it is true they have peaked-is the large immigration program, which I support fundamentally. But the underlying contributor to the pressure on housing prices is an immigration program which has continued to increase in this year. I do not complain about that, I simply point out that house prices are unlikely to collapse, that they are moderating and there is a very significant possibility that they will increase in the coming months, if not in a year’s time. Put all those pieces together and you see the preconditions for an interest rate rise. The reality is that the government knew this. It knew when it was bringing down the budget that this was a very substantial risk. If you look at the statement of risks in the budget, you will see that it points to these sorts of risks. Why? Because Peter Costello does not write budget statement No. 1. The people who write budget statement No. 1 are the Treasury. The Treasury need to cover all possibilities so that no-one can say that they got it wrong. parliamentarians can say, ‘Treasury got it wrong.’ If you go through the fine print, you can see in the statement of risks that Treasury are fully aware of the potential consequences of this budget. theText: It is an honest disclosure.

speaker: Dr Emerson
theText: It is honest disclosure. They do not want to be in a position where we asLate last year, Martin Parkinson, a senior Treasury officer, gave a speech to an economic forum where he pointed out that any budget is just a series of point estimates. By that I interpret him to mean that you can only make your best guess about each of those things, but around each point there is a substantial risk. I am saying that, around the budget estimates, there are very substantial risks associated with the settings of that budget. I do not want it to be the case that, if interest rates rise, anyone can believe that Labor supported the budget. We did not. We did not support the budget on the grounds of equity-that is, the fairness of the tax cuts. I am putting on record again tonight that we do not support the budget on the grounds of macroeconomic management either. I want to go on to some of the longer term opportunities that were lost in this budget. We are talking about capacity constraints, a reform-lazy government that has surfed on the record productivity growth generated out of the economic reform program of the Hawke and Keating years. Wouldn’t you think that a government would say: ‘Wow, what a gift! This is tremendous. Hawke and Keating have unleashed this productivity growth for us. We’ll make sure we keep it going by investing in the new sources of productivity growth in the country: education and new ideas in the form of innovation and infrastructure.’ But a reform-lazy government has failed to do that. Those hard-won increases in productivity as a result of the reform program have now turned negative. In the year 2004, productivity growth in this country not only slowed; it turned negative. Some of that might be statistical aberration or cyclical factorsany such possibility-but if you were a government that was concerned about the long-term economic management of this country, you would be very worried about productivity growth turning negative when, again, our competitors around the world are making sure that they are investing in the new sources of productivity growth. What does this government have against government in public investment in educationpublic investment in schools, vocational education and universities? The fact of the matter is that with the most recent fee increases-25 per cent increases in HECS and an expanded system whereby up to 35 per cent of places at universities can now be taken by full-fee paying Australian students assisted by a scheme called FEE-HELP-the private returns from a university education are now getting to a point where it is just not worth it. Is this short-sighted? Of course it is. How could a government be so ideologically obsessed with private provision and funding of university education that it simply refuses to invest in access to universities in this country? So it has failed on the score of investing in the skills of this nation and in the area of research and development. Under the Hawke and Keating governments business spending on research and development, as a share of gross domestic product, skyrocketed and started making us competitive with other OECD countries, where the gap between their spending on research and development and ours was narrowing. But one of the first acts of this government when it came into office was to cut the R&D tax concession, and business spending on research and development as a share of GDP fell year after year. More recently it has lifted ever so slightly, but not relative to the rest of the world. So on the second score of investing in ideas the government has gone missing, deliberately and wantonly refusing to invest in that public good that is innovation and investment in ideas. The third area, probably the most noteworthy in terms of public commentary, is infrastructure. The government blames the states for infrastructure bottlenecks. There is no national MAIN COMMITTEE infrastructure leadership in this country. What we need is a national infrastructure advisory committee and council, and we need a national infrastructure plan. It does not mean that the Commonwealth has to be the sole investor in infrastructure. The states obviously must do so. The private sector obviously must do so. But the Commonwealth should be taking a leadership role. Labor has been advocating a national infrastructure advisory council now for about three, maybe four, years. But for reasons best known to the government, probably ideological ones or a desire to shift the burden of infrastructure spending on to the states and away from the federal budget, it will not take even that sensible measure. Finally there is the area of incentives. The government talks about the need to give incentive to high-income earners to do extra work. It has lifted the threshold for the top marginal rate of tax to $125,000 a year. The government has been saying, ‘These people need more incentive because 48½c in the dollar is such a prohibitive marginal tax rate.’ Yet many people on lower and middle incomes are facing effective marginal tax rates of at least 60c in the dollar. Many of them face at least 60c in the dollar. I say that if 48½c in the dollar is a disincentive to work then surely 60c in the dollar is a disincentive to work and to participate in the economy. To achieve what we need to do to sustain prosperity in this country for a fair Australia, we must invest in the new sources of productivity growth and increase work force participation. The government’s response to work force participation is to do virtually nothing about those high effective marginal tax rates for lowand middle-income earners but to pick on single mothers and say to single mothers, ‘You must get out and work when your child turns six.’ But the wives of millionaires are actually paid to stay at home. What sort of incentive is that? On all reasonable criteria-economic management, equity, any capacity to look beyond the next election and invest in the nation’s future-this government’s 2005-06 budget is an abysmal failure. things that I practically do not have to bring my own speech to this place. As a person who has got a PhD in something-I am not sure what-it is interesting to hear him make some remarks regarding various aspects of government policy and the effect of overseas debt. He says that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer frequently made promises to follow policies that reduced the overseas debt. If you as a government reduce your own debt by $90 billion, what better policy could you follow? What he is really suggesting is that Prime Minister Howard should go on the John Laws show, predict death and confusion and the banana republic, and deliver the recession we had to have driven by 17 and 20 per cent interest rates. The member for Rankin is suggesting that that is good government policy to reduce overseas debt. Women are going out and buying themselves remarkably cheap Chinese clothing. Qantas, which is booming as one of the few profitable airlines in the world, might go out and buy another few 747s or 777s or a couple of airbuses. Of course we will borrow money from the rest of the world. The evidence is that they are delighted to lend it to us. But they are lending it to people who are making personal decisions about business or consumption, not to the government. I heard Prime Minister Keating or Treasurer Keating tell us time and time again, ‘The government are not borrowing from overseas.’ No; they just soaked up every dollar in savings that was floating around Australia and drove everybody in the private sector overseas.
