speaker: Mr Garrett (Kingsford Smith) (8.09 Pm)
theText: This debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1)Australia has had a history of relatively balanced government finances but a persistent current account deficit, resulting in higher real rates. This links to skills, to the question and the issue of building an innovative export sector. But it also leads to the question of the long-term stability of the Australian economy. The current account deficit is of real concern and is something that was not addressed in this budget. Interestingly enough, when the Treasurer spoke about bringing down the budget, he spoke about sustainability, and I will come back to that later as I speak. But there are structural issues at play which the budget does not address. In respect of the current account deficit, CS First Boston estimated that our current account deficit would be more than 10 per cent of GDP if we had not had the current commodities boom. A figure of 10 per cent of GDP is a truly preposterous and clearly unsustainable figure. On the issues of welfare, the government’s welfare to work initiatives are really churn and burn policy failure. Changes to the disability support pension will mean that new entrants will be about $77 a fortnight worse off. When the budget seeks to address issues of welfare, namely by moving people from so-called welfare to work, what it really does is move people on a disability pension to a payment, Newstart, which has a high withdrawal rate. Changes in the way people are assessed do not take into account illnesses, such as mental illnesses, that many of these people have where symptoms can change over time. The government’s changes to single-parenting payments are, we believe, unfair and unworkable. By making single parents look for part-time work when their youngest child turns six, the government seems to be punishing sole parents. There does not appear to be much proper assistance to enable them to move from welfare to work. How many workplaces will be willing to provide flexibility so parents can get their children off to school in the morning and then pick them up in the afternoon? What about when kids are unwell and cannot go to school? The problems multiply. Then there is the question of employing people with disabilities, Madam Deputy Speaker. Even the Australian government has not managed to employ large numbers of people with disabilities-the rates in the figures available to us show that since 1996 the percentage of Australian Public Service employees with a disability has fallen from 5.6 per cent to 3.8 per cent. If the government will not employ people with a disability then how can they expect other employers to do so? A person with a disability who does not earn any private income currently receives around $482 a fortnight, but after 1 July 2006 on the new Newstart allowance this same person’s income falls to about $399 a fortnight. A single person on the current disability support pension who earns $500 of private income a fortnight receives $830.90 at present. From1 July this same person’s total income will fall to $655.30. That is a significant decrease in the income available to these Australians who are amongst the most disadvantaged in our community. I want to refer in this speech to the St Vincent de Paul Society report which was released on Monday. It makes for interesting reading and it backs up some of the comments that have been made on this side of the House that the government in this budget is really allowing inequality to increase. The report, named The reality of income inequality in Australia, says: Contrary to recent assertions by the Government and certain researchers, income inequality in Australia is growing. MAIN COMMITTEE What that report shows is that real mean incomes for low-income earners grew at 12 per cent between 1994-95 and 2002-03. For high-income earners real mean weekly income rose by 16 per cent. What this shows is that the government really has said to us that poor people are going to be better offA division having been called in the House of RepresentativesSitting suspended from 8.18 pm to 8.33 pm inequality amongst Australians is shown in a report from the St Vincent de Paul Society called The reality of income inequality in Australia, which was released on Monday this week. It says: Contrary to recent assertions by the Government and certain researchers, income inequality in Australia is growing. The statistics that this report refers to show that real mean income-that is, average incomefor low-income earners grew by 12 per cent between 1994-95 and 2002-03 but that, for highincome earners, real mean weekly income rose by some 16 per cent. Clearly there is a discrepancy. The statistics do not look too bad until you follow them through, when you see that the increases equate to an actual increase of $32.28 for low-income earners and $156 for highincome earners. There is a vast difference, and the issues of inequity that lie behind our opposition to the budget can be seen clearly in these figures. I note that the report is also critical of the government’s budget. It says: ... there is no doubt that income inequality will grow even further once the tax cuts and welfare reforms are implemented. The debate about infrastructure, the predominance of those discussions within the House and the lack of real attention in the budget to infrastructure issues are one of the key features I want to address tonight. We can make the claim that the government is dropping the ball with regard to funding for infrastructure in Australia. The Deputy Prime Minister made a lunchtime announcement recently that the federal government would be taking over the ports of Australia. As the member for the electorate of Kingsford Smith, which houses one of the most important ports, Port Botany, I can inform the House that this was news to the port authorities, the local councils and the state government. Nevertheless, I think the real issue with the budget is that, because of the surplus that has been generated from the tax that has been taken, particularly through the minerals boom, Australia has never had a better opportunity to ensure that we set a platform for long-term sustainable growth. But when we look at the budget we cannot see any substantial initiatives about what that platform might be. We have a future fund, which I will refer to later, but otherwise there are no substantial initiatives to deal with what has been called a bottlenecked infrastructure crisis. There is no real sense that this is being considered by Treasury or by the Treasurer. When we look at the sketchy details that have been given to us about the future fund, we see that the premise of the future fund is a false one-that is, to pay ongoing superannuation obligations. The Productivity Commission, the government’s own Intergenerational report and long-term cost reports show that the public sector superannuation liability will be declining as a share of GDP over the next 40 years; and it is clear that, even with surplus budgeting MAIN COMMITTEE

speaker: Mr Garrett
theText: As I was saying before the division, the real effect in terms of incomesuch as the Treasurer has projected, those liabilities will be met. So there is a question about what will happen to the future fund, to what ends it will be put and who will benefit from participating in it. I notice with interest an article by Alan Kohler in the Financial Review of 11 May where he says: ... the Future Fund (that is, gaining the effect of compound interest by locking up the money in the RBA bank account, investing it a bit better and reinvesting the income) could produce decades of Liberal Party hegemony. He is saying that it could greatly assist the Liberal Party over the coming decades. Whether this is true or not, we do not know. What we do know is that we have not got a sufficient amount of information in the parliament to enable us to have confidence that the future fund, as proposed by the Treasurer, is an appropriate use of those future surpluses. Australia is gripped by drought. The country is literally drying up as we watch. Farming communities are experiencing great stress, and there is an intolerable burden upon them, particularly those in marginal areas, as they seek to maintain the productivity of their land without any rainfall. I said in my first speech in the House that climate change is the most pressing issue that this country and the global community face, and I restate that tonight. We are in the warmest autumn, I think, on record. Three of the last 10 years were the driest years that this country has faced. If ever there was a challenge that Australia really had to come to grips with, it is the challenge not only of climate change but also of the impact that drought will have upon our farming communities and ultimately upon farm exports. There was not much provision in this budget for drought relief-although I do note, and welcome, that that has in part been addressed subsequently. More importantly, no consideration was given in the budget to long-term issues of sustainability-the sustainability of our use of landscape, which ultimately is the sustainability of our economy. Nowhere do we see something that is quite common in company reports-that is, triple bottom line reporting. We do not have any reporting in the nation’s accounts that gives us an indication as to the impact or cost that the national economy has upon those things which are not costed-namely, the natural capital of this country: the air, the water and the soil. As members would know, triple bottom line reporting, or sustainability reporting, is an attempt in the nation’s sets of accounts to put a value on environmental and social externalities and, by so doing, to provide a more accurate representation of the country’s overall health. Wealth becomes health. A number of institutions, eminent academics and governments have argued for some time for the need to increase the level of environmental and social reporting-and, in fact, some parts of Europe have begun the process. Speaking as someone who has recently come into the parliament, who has a passionate concern about the environment and about the long-term sustainability prospects for this country, I am astonished that it is not addressed in the national budget. After all, we rely on that environment for our economic as well as our social and environmental well-being. The European Union, the Australian Collaboration, Environment Business Australianumerous authorities and academic institutions have proposed something akin to triple bottom line reporting. There are a number of good reasons to do it, not least of which is that many people consider that the environment is as important as the economy in determining their quality of life. There are various opinion polls around, but I refer to a European Union study MAIN COMMITTEE which shows that about 88 per cent believe that environmental concerns should be taken into account when economic or employment policy is developed. It is true that environmental awareness and concern in terms of poll figures here in Australia may have plateaued in the late eighties and early nineties, although, as with all polling, it certainly depends on the question that is asked. For instance, the Lowy Institute recently reported a large-scale poll on Australia’s international obligations. It asked people what they rated as the most important issues that Australia should take into account for foreign policy. Equal numbers of people believed that the environment-as well as job, employment and security issues-ought to be dominant. In the absence of strong environmental leadership, though, there is no doubt that the public concern may wax and wane somewhat. But underlying these remarks is the fact that environmental well-being is absolutely critical to our economic as well as our social health. The closest thing that we have to an integrated report to consider the environment in Australia is the Australian Bureau of Statistics project called MAP-Measures of Australia’s Progress. It contains economic, social and environmental indicators, but the project only provides us with summary information, and it is only intended to be used in conjunction with other reports like the budget; whereas really it should be embedded in the budget. BeforeI came into the parliament, I was involved with something called the Australian Collaboration, which was a collection of churches, the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia, aid organisations, a conservation organisation and others. Amongst their deliberations and recommendations was an identification of the need to establish a comprehensive, regular and independent reporting procedure for trends in human well-being. I think people are calling out for this. It is important for us as parliamentarians to understand the economic jargon that is associated with bringing down a budget as best we can and it is important to communicate to the public about it-but so are issues which go to people’s well-being, and the environment is certainly one of them. I note that the Australian Collaboration recommended a number of initiatives which would help to bring into place independent reporting procedures for trends in human well-being. They include regular, comprehensive and independent national reporting of social, environmental and economic trends. At present, where that reporting exists, it is in disparate places and is not drawn together in one easily accessible or comprehensible strain. The recommended initiatives include annual preparation of a new set of composite indicators that provide continuous measurements so we know how we are going. Nowhere could this be more important than with climate change or evaporation rates, for example, in our dams and rivers at present. The Australian Collaboration also recommended the introduction of comparable reporting regimes in all states so that we can form a national snapshot of the environmental state at a given point in time. And, of course, it recommended that government agencies assist this by publishing triple bottom line reporting and that public corporations, universities and community organisations also publish triple bottom line reporting-and already a number of them do that. Progressive corporations understand that there are environmental and social responsibilities, and it would be very important to see those in this budget. speaker: Mr Pyne (Sturt
theText: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Ageing) (8.44Ageing has been kind enough to give me since the election that have caused a bit of concern since the budget was handed down. In three areas some misinformation has been raised in the community and in the media, particularly by the shadow minister for health. They include community concern over the Codex, community concern over the country of origin labelling issue and the concern raised by the shadow minister for health over spending on mental health. In the appropriations debate tonight, I would like to put to put to rest the three concerns that have been raised. Mental health is a shared responsibility between federal, state and territory governments, business and consumer groups alike, consumers and carers. Mental illness is not discriminatory; it affects everyone either directly or indirectly. With one in five Australians suffering from a mental health disorder in any one year and three-quarters of all mental health problems beginning before the age of 25, it becomes every Australian’s concern. To help combat these alarming statistics, the Australian government has done a great deal over recent years. Between 1995-96 and 2001-02, the Australian government’s own expenditure on mental health care increased by 47 per cent in real terms, from $770 million to $1.145 billion. This included funding for the medical benefits schedule to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme and funding provided under the National Mental Health Strategy to facilitate further mental health reform for the first and second national mental health plans. Through the Australian health care agreements of 2003-08 the Australian government is providing funding of up to $331 million to all states and territories to facilitate further mental health reform under the National Mental Health Strategy. A further $66 million in Commonwealth ownpurpose outlays funding has been allocated for national reform activities. The federal Labor Party have not been able to get their minds around the complexities and diversity of administering mental health in Australia. The recent scare campaign run by the opposition health spokeswoman, the member for Lalor, about mental health funding and the better outcomes for the mental health program showed us what a shallow wading pool the Labor frontbench has emerged from in recent years. Madam Acting Deputy Speaker Bishop, it certainly is not the frontbench that was in office when I first came into parliament in 1993, when you had already been here for some time. These days, Labor are more concerned with scoring cheap political points than considering for a second the real concerns their scare campaign might have caused amongst mental health groups and those suffering from mental illnesses. In fact, it is an indictment on the Labor Party. It is interesting that the member for Lalor, who came to parliament only in recent years, could be their spokeswoman for health, a very important area of government policy, and also the Manager of Opposition Business in the House. I am sure it frightens many long-term Labor supporters, members of parliament and former cabinet ministers to see the Labor Party sunk to the depths that they have unfortunately sunk to in recent years, although on this side of the House we welcome the position of the Labor Party. It makes it much easier for us, but it is sad for public policy when people of such limited public experience can be as important in the opposition as the member for Lalor is these days. Federal Labor remain an empty vessel when it comes to mental health. They are without ideas and without policies or even a vague intention of announcing any and have recognised that mental health is an excellent whipping boy for cheap political stunts and scaremongering. MAIN COMMITTEE On the other hand, the coalition government continue to champion the cause of mental health in Australia. We named and shamed the state governments who have neglected their state mental health systems for so long, and now we see mental health becoming targeted spending areas in state government budgets. The coalition have put mental health back on the agenda and made it a priority for state government spending. It will horrify members of the House to know that, after deinstitutionalisation in the late eighties and early nineties at the state level, for every $6 the states had spent on institutionalisation in mental health, $5 was returned to state government coffers and $1 was spent on community support for the mentally ill. From that decision of the states back in the late eighties and nineties and from their failure to support the mentally ill in the community have come many of the woes that the mentally ill are experiencing in Australia today and that we trying to ameliorate at the federal government level. Remember that, in fact, the federal government has no constitutional jurisdiction in the area of mental health, and yet one-third of every dollar spent on mental health in Australia comes from the Commonwealth. The Australian government’s Better Outcomes in Mental Health Care program has assisted GPs with education and training to help them deliver care to patients with mental health problems. We are reaffirming the Australian government’s commitment to the prevention of, and early intervention in, mental illness in the community and we have committed $228.5 million over four years to 2008-09 for the best practice management of patients with mental health. The $228.5 million is available to continue to fund the better outcomes in mental health initiative, with $102 million committed in the budget and $40.5 million for the expansion of the initiative announced as part of the government’s mental health election commitment. This additional funding will increase access to allied health professionals and allow greater focus on rural and remote primary mental health care through better outcomes in mental health. In addition, there is $86 million for a new Medicare chronic disease item including patients with mental health problems. The highly successful national initiative on depression beyondblue also continues to raise the awareness of depression at the same time as breaking down the stigma of this insidious illness. I think it is no secret to members of the House that having Jeff Kennett, the former Premier of Victoria, as chairman of beyondblue has dramatically raised the profile of mental illness in Australia. He often says to me that, yes, he has raised the national consciousness about mental health but, in lifting up that rock and exposing the slaters, centipedes and snails that exist underneath, he has highlighted the problem and now governments have to try and fix it. That is what we have been trying to do. To that end the Australian government has provided a further $40 million over five years to expand the work of beyondblue. You would remember, Madam Deputy Speaker Bishop, that beyondblue began as a Kennett government initiative. Sadly, Mr Kennett lost the election, but Mr Bracks picked up the idea as the Premier of Victoria and, to his credit, put money into beyondblue. Every state followed suit except New South Wales-the state from which the Deputy Speaker comes. They started their own group called Black Dog. It is unusual that New South Wales needs to have their own group; I do not know why. But they have their own organisation. These days beyondblue is largely funded by the Commonwealth government, with the states’ support, and we are very pleased to fund it. The funding supports early intervenMAIN COMMITTEE tion, encourages research and improves information about depression. The funding will also assist beyondblue to establish a national postnatal depression screening and follow-up program for new mothers. Mr Cameron Thompson-Hear, hear! in fact, beyondblue did an excellent research program into postnatal depression as one of its key signatures in the last couple of years. Now, with our support, that is being expanded into a service delivery program so that the research does not just sit there-so that it does not just get talked about at conferences and forums and evaluated et cetera but actually becomes a real program for new mothers about postnatal depression. We are also helping beyondblue to target workplace depression by continuing to provide a voice on care and treatment matters. The organisation beyondblue works with many different partners across Australia, including the Alzheimer’s Association, the Australian Football League, the Australian Rotary Health Research Fund, the Centre for Adolescent Health, Jeans West, Inspire Foundation and Lifeline. When left untreated, mental health problems like depression and anxiety lead to serious alcohol and substance abuse problems. Half of all young people with alcohol and substance abuse problems can directly attribute them to untreated or poorly treated mental health issues. Three-quarters of all mental health problems begin before the age of 25. Young people with mental health problems will benefit from the Australian government’s $60.9 million election commitment to boost funding over the five years from 2004-05. The initiative will support the health care system in the detection, early intervention and management of young people with mental health problems, including those with complex mental health needs related to substance abuse. The initiative will also improve access for young people to appropriate services and ensure better links and coordination between services for young people in their local areas. The youth mental health initiative is something that the Minister for Health and Ageing and I are working on right now, with a view to making announcements later this year about exactly how that money will be spent and on what it will be spent. Mental health and suicide prevention are obviously linked. While the government continue to invest and develop policies targeting help for those with depression and other mental health problems, we are also investing in suicide prevention measures. Under the National Suicide Prevention Strategy the Australian government has committed approximately $10 million since 1999 for addressing suicide prevention in a range of population groups across their lifespan, including young people and other groups identified as being at risk. The two largest spikes for suicide across the lifespan are the youngest people and the oldest people. Before 1999 the government’s program was to in fact target young people alone. I am glad to say that since 1999 we have expanded the policy across all age groups. I was in New Zealand recently meeting with the minister who is responsible for suicide prevention in New Zealand. This year, in 2005, they have just adopted our strategy of dealing with a whole lifespan rather than just young people. So it is good to see the government program being exported across the Tasman, where they do not need to recreate the wheel but can pick up some of the work that we have been doing. MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Appropriation Bill No 2 2005 2006 Appropriation Parliamentary Departments Bill No 1 2005 2006 Appropriation Bill No 5 2004 2005 Appropriation Bill No 6 2004 2005

speaker: Mr Pyne
theText: The honourable member for Blair says hear, hear and well he might because,Implementation of the National Suicide Prevention Strategy is guided by LIFE, a framework for prevention of suicide and self-harm in Australia which provides a strategic framework for national action to alleviate suicide and promote mental health and resilience across the Australian population. Over 170 community based initiatives totalling over $22 million are being funded across states and territories according to locally identified priorities. The Australian government is currently considering recommendations put forward by the National Advisory Council for Suicide Prevention for funding under the National Suicide Prevention Strategy until June 2006. All the above activities represent a long-term investment in the social and emotional well-being of Australian communities, but they also have the potential to achieve cost savings for the community. We have lots of friends that work with us tirelessly on the mental health crusade, and we would not be able to make any headway without them. We thank our friends at beyondblue, SANE and Lifeline; all the members of the Mental Health Council of Australia, the Australian Divisions of General Practice and the Psychological Society; and all the GPs and allied health services. In the academic world, the college of psychiatrists and general practice keep the training going. There are many others who relentlessly work to support those suffering with a mental illness, particularly their families and friends. We acknowledge their strong commitment and the extraordinary effort that they make to help their loved ones have as normal a life as possible and, quite frankly, to save the government and the Australian taxpayer vast amounts of money through the unpaid care which they provide to their children and to their friends. There are two other issues in my area of responsibility that do not touch on mental health but that I would like to touch on tonight. One is Codex and one is the country of origin labelling issues, both of which have come up with some drama in the last couple of weeks. On the matter of Codex, in Australia vitamin and mineral supplements are regulated as complementary medicines under the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989-as you would know, Madam Acting Deputy Speaker Bishop, having had some experience in the area of complementary medicines over your political lifetime. They are required to meet the same standards of quality and safety as other types of complementary medicines, and the TGA is responsible for the regulation of these medicines in Australia. In some other countries these products are regulated as foods and are subject to the standards and guidelines that apply to food. The Codex Alimentarius Commission was established in 1963 by two United Nations organisations: the Food and Agriculture Organisation and the World Health Organisation. Its main purpose is to protect consumer health and to ensure fair practices in international food trade through the development of food standards and guidelines. Codex standards and guidelines are developed by committees of the commission, which are open to all member countries, including Australia. The Codex Committee on Nutrition and Foods for Special Dietary Uses has developed draft guidelines on vitamin and mineral food supplements. The draft Codex guidelines on vitamin and mineral food supplements specifically state that they apply in countries where vitamin and mineral supplements are regulated as foods. As these products are regulated as medicines in Australia they will not be affected by the proposed Codex guidelines. The TGA is aware that many consumers have expressed concerns that the draft guidelines on vitamin and mineral food supplements, as developed by the Codex Alimentarius Commission, will MAIN COMMITTEE have an effect on the regulation of vitamin and mineral supplements in Australia. The proposed Codex guidelines on vitamin and mineral supplements will not apply in Australia and will have no impact on the way these types of products are regulated in Australia. I can assure all those people who are genuinely concerned about the role of the Codex Alimentarius Commission in the regulation of our vitamin and mineral supplements that the Codex guidelines will not apply in this country for the very simple reason that we do not regulate vitamin or mineral supplements as foods; we regulate them as medicines. As a consequence, the Codex guidelines-for all, I am sure, their great benefits-will have no impact at all on the way our vitamin and mineral supplements are regulated in Australia. So all those people who keep emailing me, particularly from Queensland-may I say to the honourable member seated here-do not need to continue to do so because I can assure them that they have nothing to be concerned about. There has been a similar level of public interest in the country of origin labelling issue. Food Standards Australia New Zealand works to protect the health and safety of people in Australia and New Zealand by maintaining a safe food supply. It is a bi-national, independent statutory authority that develops food standards for composition, labelling and contaminants-including microbiological limits-that apply to all foods produced or imported for sale in Australia and New Zealand. FSANZ has recently sought public comment on the Draft assessment report: proposal P292-country of origin labelling of food. FSANZ was seeking to amend the current requirements for the country of origin labelling of food to bring the labelling requirements for unpackaged foods into line with the general labelling provisions of the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Code and to address the inconsistencies between the current transitional standard of the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Code and Australia’s World Trade Organisation obligations. proposed that, where foods are sold unpackaged, the standard require that displayed with the food, or provided or made available to the purchaser on request, is a statement identifying the country of origin of the food or a statement indicating that the food is imported. Obviously Australian consumer and industry groups were concerned that giving retailers the option to make the country of origin information available only upon the request of the purchaser might create a less transparent system, making it more difficult to be sure you are purchasing good Australian produce. Currently the code requires that there be identification of the country of origin on imported unpackaged food or an indication that the food is imported. The coalition government have already indicated that we will not support any dilution of the current code and that we wish to ensure the clear display of the country of origin on unpackaged food at the point of sale. We continue to support the mandatory labelling of imported produce because we believe consumers have the right to know when they are buying imported produce. Public consultation is part of the FSANZ process. It is required to go through public consultation when it is reviewing standards. I wish to assure all members and their constituents that there is no enthusiasm at all in the federal government for us to remove the requirement for consumers to be able to know clearly at point of sale if they are buying an imported product or a domestic product. For all of the Australian producers of fruit, vegetables and other unpackaged foods, we believe it would be a radical and unhelpful departure for consumers to have to request informaMAIN COMMITTEE tion from the retailer as to whether the product they are buying is imported or domestic. We believe it is important that, when a consumer purchases products, they can look directly at the point of sale and note whether they are buying an imported or a domestic product. I want everyone in the House and all of those people who have emailed me about this on a regular basis to know that, again, as with Codex, the government do not intend to depart from our previous policy. (Time expired) colleague the member for Hinkler in the chamber tonight. The Treasurer’s 10th budget represents yet another budget of lost opportunity, especially for central Victorian motorists who use the Calder Highway between Melbourne and Bendigo. The government continues to walk away from its commitments to this project and blame the state government for delays in completing the construction when the real cause of these delays is the federal government’s failure to adequately fund its 50 per cent share of the construction. The Calder deception has involved the federal government constantly shifting the goalposts. The Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads confirmed this last Thursday when he told a deputation from Bendigo that the state government should finance the rest of the construction and the federal government might-and I emphasise the word ‘might’provide its 50 per cent share at some stage over the next 10 years or more. Can you imagine a building construction company accepting a contract from the Commonwealth government to build a building in the hope that it might get paid some time over the next 10 years? I am sure you cannot. I do not know any company or business that would be silly enough to accept this proposition and the Victorian state government is no exception, especially with this government’s sorry record of honouring its commitments. An article prepared by the Bendigo Advertiser and published on 25 May 2005 said that the Bendigo electorate was amongst the poorest in Australia, with an estimated 15,500 people living below the poverty line. Bendigo city has unemployment levels varying between nine per cent and 12 per cent. A La Trobe University study showed an economic benefit of close to $500 million and potentially an additional 2,700 jobs for the region when the Calder project is completed. The highway in its current form is experiencing vast increases in traffic volumes and is becoming increasingly dangerous, with many accidents occurring in non-duplicated sections. The Liberal Party have promised to match the state government’s funding for this project for the past two federal election campaigns, but the federal government is currently $82 million short of its full commitment. The state government has now allocated its full 50 per cent share towards the completion of this project. It was the Howard government that first granted the Calder Highway its road of national importance status in 1996, qualifying the highway for joint Commonwealth-state funding. Now, because it suits the government’s political agenda, the Calder Highway is no longer a road of national importance. However, the Scoresby and Pakenham road projects retain their RONI status. Why? Because it suits the Howard government’s current political strategy. The Howard-Costello government have always played political poker with Victorian road funding, declaring and then abolishing Victorian roads of national importance-or RONIs-to suit their political agenda of the day. Mr Costello deals all of the cards in the game of political poker, and he has allocated another $120 million for the Scoresby project in this budget when he knows that it will never be needed. The state government has made other funding arrangeMAIN COMMITTEE
title: Appropriation Bill No 2 2005 2006 Appropriation Parliamentary Departments Bill No 1 2005 2006 Appropriation Bill No 5 2004 2005 Appropriation Bill No 6 2004 2005

speaker: Mr Gibbons (Bendigo) (9.04 Pm)
theText: I am glad to see my good friend and parliamentaryments for Scoresby and no Commonwealth funding is required. The Treasurer has not the slightest hesitation in using people’s lives as pawns to advance his personal self-interest. Mr Costello has several federal Liberal MPs whose seats surround the Scoresby corridor to protect, especially when he needs every Victorian MP’s vote he can secure for a future tilt at the prime ministership. Playing political poker is one thing, but using people’s lives as the stakes is just beyond comprehension. And this man, this Treasurer who has no hesitation in using people’s lives as pawns to get what he wants, aspires to be Prime Minister of Australia. The Howard-Costello government’s announcement of an increase in the threshold for claiming the Medicare safety net completes a series of broken promises since the 2004 federal election. The average central Victorian family budget has received yet another substantial hit since the October federal election because of the government’s backflip over its absolutely rock solid, ironclad commitment to keep the Medicare safety net in its original form. The backflip is bad enough but, in what can only be described as criminal, the government also spent a massive $20 million of taxpayers’ money in a media blitz in the run-up to the federal election telling us how the Medicare safety net policy was carefully crafted and fully costed. This latest example of this dishonest government’s willingness to say and do anything to get through an election campaign completes a sorry picture of deceit and broken promises since the October election. First we had the election promise to keep interest rates low. The Reserve Bank then lifted interest rates by 0.25 per cent, cementing Australia’s place as having one of the highest interest rate regimes in the Western world. At the same time they approved massive increases in health insurance premiums of between eight per cent and 19 per cent, after promising that their policy of the 30 per cent Medicare rebate would drive down health insurance costs. Then we had the pre-election commitment not to send more troops to Iraq, yet there are now an additional 450 soldiers on duty in southern Iraq. And now we have the increases in the Medicare safety net threshold, after what the Prime Minister and the Minister for Health and Ageing said during the election campaign with regard to keeping the Medicare safety net in its original form. At a Sydney press conference on 8 October 2004, the Prime Minister said, ‘Well, I commit to keeping it in place.’ Mr Abbott, in an interview on 6 September 2004, said, ‘That is an absolutely rock solid, ironclad commitment.’ This arrogant government is clearly showing nothing but contempt for the Australian political process and the Australian people. Average central Victorian families are paying up to $339 extra per month because of this government’s deception. At a time of rising petrol prices, families are under increasing pressure. The last thing Australians need are John Howard’s and Peter Costello’s porkies adding pressure to the family budget. The Liberals talk about sound economic management. Sound economic management Liberal style means hitting families with rising interest rates, rising child-care costs and rising medical costs. The Howard government can only manage to provide a miserable $6 by way of a tax cut for most Australian workers. The attitude of the Liberals shows that they have no understanding or respect for the plight of most Australian working men and women. Since the 2004 election the Howard-Costello government have displayed utter contempt for Australians. It has been proven that they will say and do anything to get elected-untruth after untruth hitting Australian families. The sad truth is that the Liberals perpetrate untruths and Bendigo working families pay. In the six months since the 2004 election John Howard and Peter MAIN COMMITTEE Costello have broken six of the very promises on which they were re-elected and this budget provides very little by way of relief to average wage and salary earners. No. 1, John Howard and Peter Costello broke their promise that interest rates would not rise. Their $66 billion spending spree and their neglect of the nation’s skills and infrastructure needs put upward pressure on interest rates. This has added another $579 per year to the cost of servicing a $300,000 mortgage. No. 2, Peter Costello and John Howard’s broken promise on the Medicare safety net has added $200 to health costs every year for average income families whose out-of-pocket expenses reached a new threshold of $500. For singles and higher income families the threshold was jacked up by $300 to $1,000. No. 3, John Howard and Peter Costello broke their promise to families with kids in child care to introduce an uncapped 30 per cent child-care rebate from 1 January 2005. No rebate will be available until July 2006. For a typical family with a child under five years of age in full-time day care this means that they will be $1,557 worse off this year because they will have to wait until January 2006 for any rebate. No. 4, Peter Costello and John Howard broke their promise to single income families to increase the maximum rate of family tax benefit part B by $300 from 1 July 2005. The cash bonus available in 2005-06 was reduced to $150. In other words, that was $150 less than they promised at the election. No. 5, the Howard and Costello government broke their 2001 election promise that the private health insurance rebate would reduce health insurance premiums. And that has been broken again, with an average eight per cent increase in premiums since March this year. That has added $164 per year to average premiums for a family with hospital ancillaries cover. No. 6, as I said before, the Howard and Costello government said before the election that there would be no further addition to the number of troops deployed in Iraq. Now there are an additional 450 troops serving in that part of the world under extremely dangerous circumstances. Australia’s current interest rate of 5.5 per cent is among the highest when compared with those of other advanced economies around the world. Australians are already paying among the highest interest rates when compared to other economies that Prime Minister Howard and Treasurer Costello like to compare Australia with. In the United States, the federal fund rate is about 2 per cent. In Europe the Central Bank’s key interest rate for Euro economies is around 2 per cent. The Bank of Canada’s overnight rate is 2. 5 per cent. In Japan the official discount rate is just 0.1 per cent. If you want to look at housing loan interest rates in 2005, you will see that the reality is that Australia’s rates are also among the highest in the Western world, significantly higher than those in the US and the UK and more than double that of Japan’s. This completely buries the myth peddled by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer that the coalition will always preside over lower interest rates. Another 0.25 per cent interest rate increase would mean the standard variable rate would increase from 7.3 per cent to 7.55 per cent, resulting in an additional $48 per month on an average monthly mortgage repayment for a $300,000 loan over 30 years. That is what Australian working families have to look forward to. National statistics show that sales of new houses and home units fell a further 4.5 per cent in January to a new four-year low. Housing Industry Association new home sales figures show that fear of interest rate rises continues to impact on the new home market, with house sales down 1.5 per cent and unit sales down a massive 21.2 per cent. The Prime Minister and MAIN COMMITTEE Treasurer are constantly trying to portray the coalition as the government of low interest rates when in fact Australia’s interest rates are among the highest in the developed world. Regional Victorian motorists have paid a staggering $198 million more in petrol taxes since the introduction of the GST, with central Victorian motorists contributing a massive additional $22 million to the Howard-Costello government’s fuel tax rip-off. The Howard-Costello government claimed the GST would lead to a drop in some indirect taxes, but when it came to petrol taxes the GST was used to conceal a grotesque petrol rip-off. The fuel fraud was revealed at a national trucking convention in Newcastle where my parliamentary colleague the shadow minister for regional development and roads, Kelvin Thomson, proved that, if the government had stuck to pre-GST fuel taxes, it would have reaped $41 billion in the past four years. Instead, it was estimated that it collected more than $44 billion. Spread evenly across the nation, this made regional Victoria’s share of this secret windfall around $198 million. I suspect our true share of that vile amount is even more than the $198 million, given that country people pay more per litre for their fuel and, according to transport economists, make more long car trips than city motorists. Country people are even more affected by the secret taxing because of the transport costs component in absolutely everything they consume. The country transport industry has every right to feel angry about this. In his address to the Australian trucking convention, the member for Wills said that in 2000-01 total petrol tax revenues were $8.38 billion. In 2004-05, it was estimated the tax take would be $9.32 billion, almost $1 billion more than in 2001. By the end of this financial year, the federal government will have collected an estimated $44 billion in petrol taxes since the GST came in-$36 billion in excise and $8 billion from the GST. If the government had stuck with the pre-GST petrol tax arrangements, it would have collected $41 billion, or $3.31 billion less during this period. Even allowing for the 1.5c per litre cut in March 2001 and for revenue forgone as a result of the nonindexation of petrol excise, the Howard government is still over $3 billion better off in petrol taxes since the introduction of the GST. The Howard-Costello government’s approach was to walk away from its responsibility to fund and maintain Australia’s national highway network while its AusLink strategic regional roads component was used as a $93 million slush fund in coalition held or targeted seats during the last election campaign. The miserable $6 tax cut for most Australian wage earners will disappear when they fill their vehicle with fuel each week. The Howard-Costello government admitted in Senate estimates on 14 February 2005 that most of the AusLink strategic regional project funds established by legislation currently or recently before the parliament were dished out during the election campaign without following any application or assessment processes. The coalition ignored the commitments in the AusLink white paper of June 2004 that there would be an application process, a call for submissions, and project development and assessment guidelines, which would then be published in late 2004. The government admitted in Senate estimates that this simply did not happen-it did not happen before the election and it has not happened since. The Liberal and National coalition government has turned AusLink into yet another slush fund for the government’s political benefit, which would explain the coalition’s appalling record in inadequately funding the Calder Highway development. Legislation setting up new discretionary funds is currently before the parliament, and Labor has referred the AusLink bills to a Senate committee for scrutiny. The coalition committed almost $100 million out of a MAIN COMMITTEE total of $150 million allocated on the AusLink strategic Regional Partnerships program during the election campaign. The Department of Transport and Regional Services conceded in Senate estimates that there would be no cost-benefit analysis of the projects. Despite having committed almost two-thirds of the money as election commitments, Minister Lloyd still saw fit to tell the Australian Local Government Association national general assembly on 10 November 2004 that the AusLink regional strategic fund was: ...based on competitive applications, so the enlistment of your local Federal Membersand get thisCoalition and Labor to advance a well documented case for serious projects is keenly awaited. There were not too many Labor projects funded, let me tell you. This raises more serious questions about the way the government do business. They promised a more strategic approach to land transport planning under AusLink but went ahead and used the money allocated to engage in old-fashioned pork-barrelling in the run-up to the recent federal election. This budget contains $11.1 million for the Australian Defence Force for assistance in the Boxing Day tsunami affected regions. The Prime Minister in his usual fashion has exploited this tragedy for his own self-promotion. He has certainly got his $11 million’s worth of value from this commitment. Prime Minister Howard has virtually admitted that he made the men and women of the HMAS Kanimbla spend useless time at sea so that he could seek the glory of welcoming the ship back home after it had concluded its duties in the tsunami ravaged regions. The PM has been caught out playing politics with Australian service personnel who are crew members of HMAS Kanimbla. The ADF people on Kanimbla had performed an outstanding tour of duty in Aceh, where they were confronted with almost unimaginable death and destruction resulting from the Boxing Day tsunami. They finished their task and were headed home when they were turned around to assist in the aftermath of the second earthquake off the Indonesian coast. Faced with a catastrophe of enormous proportions in Aceh and given that they had lost nine of their colleagues in the tragic Sea King accident during the second tour of duty, they should have been given every opportunity to get home to their families at the earliest possible time. A simple study of the cruising speed of the ship and a comparison with the officially reported time it arrived in Townsville showed that the Kanimbla could have arrived in Sydney as early as the Thursday, two days before its Saturday arrival. What makes this appalling matter even worse is that Prime Minister Howard told the John Laws radio program yesterday that, while he had not ordered the ship to wait, that was certainly the understanding that the commander of the ship expressed. When a commander of the ship gets a request from the Prime Minister that he would like to be there to welcome the ship, that is taken as a paramount order; and that is what happened. Certainly that is the understanding from at least one unnamed officer on the Kanimbla, who told the same radio program, ‘We were ordered to slow our ship down to arrange our arrival for shortly after the Prime Minister’s flight was due to land home from Greece.’ The simple facts are that the Kanimbla arrived outside Townsville Harbour-and you would be well aware of that, Mr Deputy Speaker Lindsay, because that is part of your region-at 6.55 am on Tuesday, 26 April. Townsville Harbour is approximately 1,080 nautical miles from Sydney Harbour. The RAN web site states that the Kanimbla travels at 20 knots per hour. One thousand and eighty nautical miles divided by 20 knots or nautical miles per MAIN COMMITTEE hour equals 54 hours, or 2¼ days travel. Kanimbla could very easily have arrived at its base at Garden Island on or shortly after midday on Thursday, 28 April. She arrived home on Saturday, 30 April around 1 pm. The Prime Minister is reported to have arrived home in Sydney at midday on Saturday, the same day. John Howard has been caught out in a vain grab for glory at the expense of military people who had already been asked to do so much and who had already made substantial sacrifices. It was opportunistic, shabby and shameful, and he should admit his arrogance and apologise. Dr JENSEN (Tangney) (9.23 pm)-All this criticism of the coalition’s economic policy is interesting, particularly on issues such as interest rates, when all one has to do is have a look at the records to see who has a better record as far as economic management is concerned. Labor has decided to oppose the tax cuts theoretically, as a matter of principle. Let us reiterate this: Labor does not want to give any Australians tax cuts at the moment. Labor is proposing a tax cut regime whereby Australians would get their tax cut in 2008. Clearly, that is not a situation that we should seriously consider. It is worse than this. They are causing confusion for business as far as tax schedules are concerned. The schedules have been tabled but there is no word as to whether the schedules will be disallowed or not. This has thrown businesses into confusion. The crazy thing about this is that there is really no hope of achieving anything. The tax cuts in the budget will be passed in the new Senate and all they can do is delay things. This opposition to tax cuts is simply spoiler tactics to make the Leader of the Opposition look tough, but it is to no avail. It is a case of Labor putting politics before the national interest or the individual interests of Australian taxpayers. God help us if we should get a Beazley government, where politics would be the primary issue of importance and politics would completely override policy. As I said, the opposition leader is attempting to look tough. This move clearly demonstrates that he is trying to walk both sides of the street yet again. The opposition leader knows that he cannot stop the tax cuts in the medium term, so he sees this as a risk-free strategy for Labor: all care, no responsibility. On the one hand, he cannot stop the cuts, which deep down he knows are in the national interest; on the other, he believes that he will appear to be a leader of principle. What principle? The Labor position is one that is entirely damaging to all concerned-apart from Labor’s perception of political advantage. It is stopping every Australian taxpayer from getting a tax cut that they so richly deserve and therefore it damages the financial position of many households. Maybe the $6 tax cut does not mean very much to the Leader of the Opposition, given that he is sitting on a very comfortable pay packet, but it means a great deal to many people waiting for tax relief. The Leader of the Opposition can afford to play fast and loose with tax relief; he can afford it. But many Australians cannot afford the unprincipled game playing that Labor are embarking on to try to gain some political credibility for the Leader of the Opposition. Newsflash for the Leader of the Opposition: you gain credibility by doing the hard yards and generating some real policy; you do not gain credibility by playing games with people’s pay or adversely interfering in business operations in a damaging way just to try to gain perceived political points. This clearly demonstrates why Australian voters did not, and do not, consider Labor fit to govern. Labor are far too fickle in playing politics over the national interest. MAIN COMMITTEE I notice that the member for Kingsford Smith is here. I am sure that he, being very environmentally aware, would be interested in my next subject: Australia’s water crisis. Water is a precious resource. In Australia, the driest inhabited continent on the planet, we cannot afford to take it for granted. Australia’s prosperity depends on a secure water supply for our houses, farms, environment and industry. A growing population and degrading river systems have shown why the nation needs new and better ways to secure water for the future. Mandatory water restrictions are now in place across each state in Australia. In Sydney, for example, as at Thursday, 26 May this year, the available water storage in Sydney’s water supply reservoirs was a mere 39.7 per cent of capacity. In my own state of Western Australia, water storage in the dams on Monday, 30 May was a meagre 25.1 per cent of total capacity. There are a few different ways that you can attack the problem of the dwindling water supply. One way is to simply move people to where the water is. However, this is a case of social engineering, and social engineering in this sort of way never works. You cannot force people to live where they really do not want to. Another way is to reduce water consumption. Of course, we have water restrictions in the capital cities, so clearly this is an avenue that is being tried, but it will only work to a certain extent. It is limiting and it clearly does not help farmers. We can use grey water recycling, but once again there is limited scope for use of this method. A method that is popular, it would appear, with the Western Australian Labor government and also with the New South Wales Labor government is desalination. However, there are significant environmental and energy costs. I do not believe that they have been anywhere near adequately evaluated. The method which we really need to look at is getting water to where it is needed. The first thing to do is to identify the best site where there is water. Twenty per cent of Australia’s rainfall flows into the Ord River catchment. There is a fantastic proposal that a constituent of mine has proposed that clearly shows out-of-the-square thinking, which is to pipe water from the north-west to Perth and the other major capital centres of mainland Australia. The cost would be about $55 billion to $70 billion. However, this is a cost that would not be borne by the taxpayer. The cost of delivered water would be between 18c and 23c per kilolitre in constant 2005 dollars over a period of 50 years. In effect, the cost of water would, in real terms, be reducing over this period. As I said, this system, at essentially no cost to the taxpayer, would from the outset be in public hands. How is this achievable? The idea is to sell water rights to farmers and other interested parties for a period of 50 years for around $8,500 per megalitre. This would give owners of the land that the pipe crosses approximately $22,000 per kilometre right of way for easement. Water supply to water rights owners would be charged at about 3c per kilolitre to provide funds for ongoing operational expenses. The water rights would be a tradeable commodity for the water rights owners-in other words, the farmers. The idea is that about 80 per cent of the water rights would be marketed for agriculture and about 20 per cent would be for urban use, which would obviously help with the urban dam situation. The pipe length would total about 7,200 kilometres. About 15 per cent of this would go through land that is suitable for irrigation. If you work on a lateral distance of up to 25 kilometres from the pipe, as far as irrigation is concerned, you can then determine the total land area. Using this, you can see that there would be a very significant economic benefit to all of Australia. MAIN COMMITTEE intervene? ability of water flows in, for instance, the Fitzroy River catchment and the role that is played by the river in aquifer regeneration in the Kimberley region. a speech, if I recall correctly, about two months ago. Domestic utilities would be able to sell the additional water that they get at about 45 per cent above cost. The water cost to the agricultural sector would be cheaper than it is for irrigation purposes now. Let us have a look at the state of affairs on this. In 1975, an acre-foot of water cost approximately $35. Currently, it is approximately $326. Clearly, looking at this, we can see that water rights would be an appreciating asset. How will farmers afford water rights? Reliable water will increase the value of the land, as I have stated. The idea is that in order to gain a loan from the bank, the landowner will purchase, in effect, an intention to purchase a water right for a cheap price, whereafter the farmer can go to the bank with a strategic business plan and obtain a loan. There is potential, as well, for any excess water-and as the member for Kingsford Smith said, there is variability in the rainfall in the areas; there is variability everywhere-in the years where there is an abundance of water. It could be purchased and fed into the Murray-Darling catchment, with the potential to assist farmers in the catchment area as well and still enable the Murray-Darling system, particularly the Murray, to have a healthy flow at the mouth of the Murray River. I commend this proposal to the House. I believe it is an excellent proposal to consider, given that, as I mentioned, there are a few different methods in which you can attack the water problem. As I have said, I do not think that moving people to where the water is will work. Reducing water consumption clearly works, but there are limitations. As far as recycling is concerned, it can only be used to a certain extent-there are limits-and with desalination there are significant environmental and energy costs. In terms of the Western Australian proposal, you are talking about 10 per cent of the base load electricity, which will be used for the desalination plant in addition to the chemicals that are put in the front end and are going to go into Cockburn Sound, which is not a well-flushed waterway. In conclusion, the way to do it is to get water where it is needed. I believe that this is an excellent proposal that really deserves consideration in terms of helping to alleviate Australia’s water crisis and to give many farmers some surety as far as water supply is concerned. and the triumph of the Costello silvertails. The government is awash with money; it is literally drowning in revenue. Spending is out of control. It has delivered tax cuts that are heavily skewed to high-income earners, and it has made virtually no serious hard decisions on spending or on tax reform. There are punitive changes regarding the disability pension and sole parent pension, and there is a very limited strategy towards seriously lifting work force participation.
